139307350.review:
What a dreadfully nihilistic, sentimental, and poignant experience Narcissu was. 
Does Narcissu have a great narrative? Not really. Does it even have great dialogue? No. Are the cgs or characters great? Nope.

What Narcissu does offer, however, is a highly realistic portrayal of two clinically-ill patients who are very rapidly succumbing to their illness; both psychically and mentally. And, in their newly founded philosophical abyss, impulsively decide to futilely fight against their environment and fate. Following that, we see both the characters on a road trip where, metaphysically, they create their own life and undergo introspection and self-discovery together. Some important questions get raised: is it the destination or the journey that matters? When faced with the prospect of death within weeks; do you surrender or precede in meaningless defiance? Is there any inherent purpose or meaning to our fleeting lives? Yadda yadda. 

Now, Narcissu does have good writing and a decent plot. But, what it does not have is good pacing, transitions, or story length. 
The pacing in this novel is far too fast--about as fleeting as Seimitsu's life. And, on top of that, the transitions and abrupt chapter endings are not only jarring, but take you out of the atmosphere. Now, the story length itself leaves very little room for your feelings to mature, and, as for the the two main characters, it's a similar story. Not only are the characters particuarly uninteresting; the dialogue itself tends to be very boring oftentimes. But, when it does hit--it hits. And, in the same vein, probably a bit more realistic all things considered.  As for the ending, it's prdictable but impactful. Yet, gets completely eroded by the sudden, jarring credits scene that info dumps/rehashes the story and the main character while cheerful music plays in the background. That, singlehandedly, almost ruined the entire experience for me. 
Aside from that, the minimalist soundtrack and CGs work greatly with the game's hallow, bittersweet, and unnerving atmosphere. 

Is it worth the 5 hours of playtime, I'd say so. And, in my opinion, Narcissu is better than the majority of short VNs, such as Planetarian. 

6/10

139298177.review:
As with many "deep" VN stories I've read, the "deep" personalities of each character seem to boil down to just saying "I don't know" and "does it matter" and "I am too afraid to make decisions or choices in life". I find this extremely annoying about japanese culture in general. I don't find indecisiveness to be realistic. Most people don't have any trouble making decisions, since weighing positives and negatives of a choice is a very straightforward and basic thought process. I feel like Japanese culture values this lack of straightforwardness in conversation as some sort of thing to be praised due to some preconception of politeness. But to me it seems like people never actually talk, they just try to tell each other as little as possible and avoid real communication out of fear of seeming too blunt. Surely this will lead to good relationships. I can see why the characters in this game would be suicidal when no one actually talks to them, instead saying "betsuni" 24/7. A good "f*** off" would fix that I think. But not really in VN vernacular to be so honest. Anyway I'll talk about the actual game.

This game doesn't have enough visuals. A lot of the time on screen there is just a grey square and text. I could count like 2-3 pictures of the female character in the first part, and those show for about 1% of the dialogue. This is really bare bones. It would be better off being a book with a soundtrack you could play while reading it.

If I had to describe the writing in this VN, it would be "thoughtful and empathetic, but strangely childish". It sets out to point out that terminally ill people feel abandoned by society, as if this is some sort of revelation people did not know about. By considering such an illness for a little bit one could divine the mental state someone having one would end up in. So this game's story doesn't really reveal something that unique regarding its central topic. But it does tell it with a lot of care so it is enjoyable to read in a way.

The second part of the story is a bit more lighthearted for a large portion of it and overall longer. It's a bit refreshing in that way, but many of the chapters amount to nothing. Chapter 5: Setsumi and Himeko eat ice cream. Setsumi learns Himeko likes cars. (we already knew that though) Chapter 6: Setsumi and Himeko plant a bulb in the garden and eat croquettes. Setsumi sees flowers and Himeko tells her they are Narcissus WOW JUST LIKE THE ONES IN THE FIRST PART OF THE GAME...is a whole chapter necessary for this? Chapter 7: They eat croquettes again. Himeko says the reason she thinks she has an illness is because she is being punished for not going to church enough as a catholic. (Yes this is all that matters to the story in the entire chapter.)

There's also a lot of "*stares at sky* ah, how lonesome it's beautiful and blue", "once again, the cicadas are singing", we don't need this every single day in the game. We understand by a sound effect or two if it's clear weather or raining etc.

Story: Solid, if overly marred by indecisive, distant communication between characters and pointless interactions
Visuals: Not good, barely any to speak of
Music: Great, probably the best aspect of the game

I don't recommend it because there are many many VNs with sad endings that you should consider before this one, which is very basic and probably not worth your time despite being free. Yuki Gotou is in it though, so maybe play just the second part to hear her if you like her voice acting. The "Opening video" for Narcissu 2nd (actually about 1 hour into the story though) has Riya as a vocalist too, which sounds really nice.

The 2nd game also tried to have some sort of deep comment on christianity (not to make it seem bad or good necessarily though) but it seems like the writer didn't understand the concept of afterlife. If you are going to die, you don't expect god to let you live suddenly by praying. You pray and follow the teachings of christianity to be saved in the afterlife. In the game the characters are getting fed up with their prayers because god doesn't magically cure their diseases. Not really how the concept of prayer works.

137945562.review:
I have read multiple VN's, seen multiple movies and series and read a lot of books. But this one stands out of the bunch. When it comes to how emotional masterpieces are created they take one of two forms. The first one is having the main focus about being a tearjerker and is there to make you cry. The other one is to teach the person reading/watching abotu something. This message can then dig so deep into your heart that you end up crying anyways. I have always found the latter one to be more impactful on my life but Narcissu stood out to me. 

Narcissu is a VN that does not have the main focus about being a tearjerker and neither does it have a specific message. The thing that makes this one special is that it does not teach you anything new but rather makes you think hard about something you already know which is about life and death. Already at a young age our bodies surpress these deep thoughts about life and death unconsciously. This is because its too deep of a topic and will bring a great deal of mental stress when thought about. This VN however forces you to think about those things which can have a drastic change on how you view your own life. That is why this VN is so powerful. 

Through this VN you will yourself be able to find your own view on life, the value of it, how you want to live your own life. Not to mention that this VN is entirely free and was made to be free. The whole purpose of this VN was for people to get a grasp on what life truly means in their own way. There is no right or wrong when it comes to this question, just how you yourself feel.

Even though the Artstyle is old and it does not seem to be of high quality at first glance every single one of these things are intentional so that you have the opportunity to dive deep into your inner thoughts. There will never be a VN quite like this one and there will never be a VN that can have this big of an impact on your life. I will say it once more. This VN is the best VN of all time when it comes to changing the person reading it. And it will probably remain that way for a very long time. 

If you ever feel like you need a change of view over your life do not hesitate to read this VN. It is totally worth it

final score 10/10

137463328.review:
5 minutes to get all achievements.

100% Achievement Guide
↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓
↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓↓
Finished Narcissu 1st (voiced)
Very simple, all you need to do is press start, select the first title, any translation and make sure that you select voiced. Once you have done this just hold down the CTRL key, wait until you finish the prologue and continue throughout all the chapters. Pressing the SPACE key furiously will take approximately an hour longer.
Finished Narcissu 1st (unvoiced)

Repeat exactly what you did the first time except select unvoiced. Also, you don't have to go and press CTRL through the whole story again, you can just easily select the last chapter (Chapter 08).
Finished Narcissu 2nd (voiced)

Now that you have finished both achievements for Narcissu 1st it is time to move on to 2nd. Select the second title, choose whatever translation and make sure that you select voiced, just like the first time. Now power through it again with CTRL.
Finished Narcissu 2nd (unvoiced)

Keep everything the same, select unvoiced and got through Chapter 19.
Finished Narcissu 2nd Epilogue

For some reason this achievement is hidden, but it only requires you to go to Epilogue & full credits. Make sure you have gotten all the other achievements before trying to get this one. Voicing does not matter.

136634234.review:
Narcissu 1st and 2nd was a fairly good visual novel. It had an emotional and thought-provoking story, even if a few elements were predictable and standard fare for this sort of story. It was also not long enough to overstay its welcome, which it easily could have done, but it also wasn't short enough to feel too fleeting. Another bonus is that the game was fully voiced, so there was more emotion that could be gained from the game. 

Despite these praises, the game, unfortunately, has very limited graphics and music. For the majority of the game, you will just be looking at a flat background with some text with a few music tracks that constantly loop. This tends to make the experience of playing this game pretty boring, as the story itself isn't exactly the most invigorating, and the game itself doesn't have much substance.

Overall, this game was a pleasant and thought-provoking read that was full of emotion. However, it was a bit boring at times due to the lack of features in the game. Despite this, I would still recommend giving it a try, especially since it is free.

one summer, one meeting, one one parting

narcissu tells the story of the 7th floor of a hospital, where it is said that patients will not return to the room for the third time.

a short story that is presented very well in terms of the speed of the story and the way it is delivered, although the story is only set in 40 days but that time is enough to make me feel close to the characters and can shed tears for what happened to them.

from patients who rarely show their emotions to patients who are very positive despite having problems with their belief in God.

narcissu promises a story that touches the heart and brings a smile, whether in part 1 or part 2.

the minim visual presentation also gives freedom of imagination to the player to give their own interpretation.

As a game that is given for free, Narcissu really gives a very good surprise in terms of story and music.

133974169.review: a short story about finding peace in death. it's short, impactful and emotional, it deals with some very serious topics which are rarely the main focus in most projects like terminal illness and religion. the game raises a lot of questions about the morality of the protagonist's actions, suicide and life itself which really make you think about what you believed thus far. the soundtrack is phenomenal and the art, although scarce, is memorable whenever it's present. "with the birth of purpose, the fear of loss also was born."

133314638.review:
[h1]If there is a prayer, then there is also a curse...[/h1]

[b]This kinetic VN can be sum up in a short Latin phrase, I've learnt at school. "Memento mori".[/b]

Narcissu took me by surprise completely. I've had no idea what I picked up (it was free on Steam, so I thought I'll give it a try). It is probably the saddest story among visual novels, I have read. Basically, it all starts in a hospice care. So, you know...there's no such a thing as good, happy ending here...
I wasn't prepared for that, as it reminded me of my close friend, who passed away, suffering from cancer few years back. Narcissu brought all the memories. Honestly, it is well written story with believable main character. Himeko (I will always call her "姫") acted, just like my friend...
It's a heartbreaking story in two parts. You will cry in both of them. Just don't forget to check epilogue, upon finishing Narcissu 2nd. It's short, but it will squeeze even more tears from you.
Tomo Kataoka made a truly unforgettable experience. Even with its predictable and sad ending, story forced me to think again about my own life and how precious it is. And if you have something to tell to your friend, family member or a lover - it's best not to wait until the last minute, because it might be too late at the end...

From technical point of view - it's nothing special, mind you - it's a novel from 2005, so resolution is low. However - it is voiced vn and soundtrack is amazing. Plus, it's completely FREE and it is one of the best titles in the genre.
Depend on your reading speed, story is around 7 hours long.

[b]Overall, if you want to read something that will get you emotional, I strongly recommend this title. Despite its technical flaws, I'm giving it 9/10 score. It's beautiful and unique. [u]The 7th Floor...damn...I don't know if I would be strong enough to be a helper there...

130614393.review:
Narcissu 1st and 2nd is a Japanese visual novel game that was released in 2005 and 2007, respectively. The game is a story about a young man named Setsumi, who is hospitalized with terminal cancer, and a girl named Himeko, who is also a patient at the hospital. The game tells the story of their relationship and their experiences with illness, death, and the meaning of life.

The game's art and music are both excellent, with beautiful backgrounds and a moving soundtrack that effectively sets the tone of the story. The writing is also well-done, with a poignant and emotional narrative that explores themes of love, loss, and hope. The characters are well-developed, and the player becomes deeply invested in their stories.

One of the game's strengths is its ability to address serious and heavy themes in a way that is both sensitive and thought-provoking. It manages to be both poignant and uplifting, while avoiding being maudlin or sentimental. The game's ending is also particularly well-done, offering a satisfying conclusion to the story while also leaving room for interpretation.

Overall, Narcissu 1st and 2nd is a powerful and moving visual novel that tells a beautiful and emotionally resonant story. It is a must-play for fans of the visual novel genre and anyone who appreciates thought-provoking storytelling.

Please note the game contain sensitive theme such as terminal illness and death, If you might find it hard to deal with, you may want to consider before playing it.

124178922.review:
A very solid read with a lot of care and attention put into the story.

In terms of the individual novels, Narcissu 1 is a proof of concept and Narcissu 2 is a prequel to it that is longer, introduces more characters, and establishes the setting in a more elaborate manner.

Both volumes feature the girl named Setsumi who, like some of the other characters from the hospital, experiences terminal illnesses. She connects the two volumes together in all stages of her illness, as you both get to experience the setting in her shoes as well as from the outside perspective of another character called Yuu.

The topic of exploration isn't so much about the nature of the disease itself, but more so about how it influences the characters, their development, relationships, perspective, among other things. The realisation that sooner or later these characters are going to die while bound to living the rest of it in the hospital or home, sets up an underlying melancholy mood. However, the story gets engaging and quite climactic as story progresses.

The character dynamic and the topics explored, as well as the overall presentation, are definitely the strong points of this visual novel.

On that note, I strongly recommend giving this one a read.

121355314.review:
9/10

Positives:
> Really good BGM for scenes
> Simple but really nice "water color" style art
> Good story
> Great way to introduce yourself to visual novels

Negatives:
> Non-interactive visual novel (might be a turn off to people who may have played a few VNs)

Review
For me, this isn't my first experience in playing visual novels. However this is my first visual that has a pretty heavy theme for its story line. The story of the both parts of the game gives you the chance to think about your view of life and really puts you in the shoes of the characters. 

Lastly, don't expect different routes or story line for Narcissu. This game is a non-interactive visual novel means there are no routes. It's basically reading a book with voice acting and a nice BGM 

With that said, I recommend this game for people who are starting or just new with the visual novel genre of games. It gives you a peek for what to expect in visual novels, specially with genre staples for the VN category. 

P.S - They really should've put a trigger warning, this game might not be healthy for everybody. Deducted a point for that because the story might rub off some people the wrong way.

𝙒𝙚𝙡𝙘𝙤𝙢𝙚 𝙩𝙤 𝙩𝙝𝙚 "𝙨𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙡𝙚 𝙘𝙡𝙚𝙖𝙣, 𝙬𝙝𝙞𝙩𝙚 𝙥𝙡𝙖𝙘𝙚 𝙬𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙘𝙚𝙞𝙡𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙨 𝙝𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙚𝙧 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙣 𝙪𝙨𝙪𝙖𝙡, 𝙖𝙣𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙬𝙞𝙣𝙙𝙤𝙬𝙨 𝙤𝙥𝙚𝙣 𝙣𝙤 𝙢𝙤𝙧𝙚 𝙩𝙝𝙖𝙣 𝙛𝙞𝙛𝙩𝙚𝙚𝙣 𝙘𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙞𝙢𝙚𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙨"

𝐀𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐠𝐚𝐦𝐞:

My mind has always been excited by the idea of the ability of any story to influence a person's thinking, his emotional state, or the ability to simply linger in his head. And to some extent it is crazy that the story is placed there by an absolutely stranger, but does not lose its closeness to you because of this.
But how does this happen? Why can absolutely anyone influence you with their own legend, what should the latter be? And everything is very simple and difficult at the same time: you need to be sincere and invest a part of yourself.
Stage-nana is the most ordinary and "everyday" developers who released an ordinary, at first glance, kinetic novel in 2007.
They operated with a soundtrack, a small amount of text and a very regressive picture at that time, but they, unlike many other developers, actually managed to give me an abyss of pleasant memories, a swarm of thoughts and a great many tender feelings. Hence my perception is clouded, and the hand draws only a positive picture of the world of this game.
But I'll try to be objective.

The plot in Narcissus tells about two sick people, a girl and a guy, who dutifully await their inevitable death, as a result of a disappointing diagnosis, on the white and sterile expanses of a special, 7th floor. But something is happening and the situation is changing dramatically.

The graphic component, as I wrote above, is at a really average level. However, this does not prevent the game from looking atmospheric and very original, especially against the background of modern novels. The same planetarium from the studio "Key" is made in a similar style and both works are iconic.

The most important part of the game is the soundtrack . Extremely subtle, dramatic and comprehensive, it literally permeates you with the most diverse emotions, making you worry, rejoice, laugh, as if you were the main character of the novel.

There is a lot of text in the game and it is written well, I did not notice any errors in the English version of the game.

𝐑𝐞𝐬𝐮𝐥𝐭:

Narcissu is a diamond among visual novels. With its budget, the difficulties of development in this segment and other difficulties at the time of the creation of the game, Stage-nana managed to immerse us in a wonderful story that can give you a whole life full of bitterness and joy in just one evening.

121087459.review: Masterpiece. Pure masterpiece through and through. Loved every moment of this journey through ideas of mortality and loss.

120770970.review:
Note: Have only finished Narcissu 2nd Side and completed it first

From the beginning to right before the Nello & Alois flashbacks began, I thought this game was simply good. It was fairly descriptive and varied in tone with a well made soundtrack but had a fair amount of issues with regards to story focus and character structure. I didn't like the lack of focus on Yuka and to a lesser extent Chihiro. I also found the pacing to be a bit too scattered and disconnected. 

However, after those flashbacks began and especially when they started to become dark, the game just absolutely blew apart my expectations and then blew them apart again. How everything just came together thematically and emotionally was just unbelievable. The thematic handling of loss of faith and the complicated feelings of grief and suicide could not have been handled better. I was completely speechless. And the music particularly "For Whose Sake" and "Route 1" complimented these strong emotions masterfully. The conclusion was just outstanding.

Ultimately, it wasn't even just how the game handled grief and existentialism and loss of faith but instead how it tackled faith itself and how it connects with the human condition. The affirming and beautiful (but absolutely not naive) presentation of religion and faith despite the terrible inevitable circumstances really gets to the heart of why faith matters so much to people and why it continues to endure. Just amazing to see such an astoundingly accurate portrayal of this by a Japanese writer.

106397256.review:
Narcissu is a minimalist kinetic novel, the art doesn't take more than 20% of the screen space with the rest of the screen being occupied by the colour of black, characters illustrations are far and in between, it doesn't have a text box and the texts that tell its story are placed in the black’s void. And while it does have voice acting, the developer suggested to play the game unvoiced for your first playthrough. Combined with the soundtrack that sings the songs of calm and sorrow, despite how it may look like the thought that the game feels cheap never comes to mind. The minimalist look gives the game a melancholic feeling and for the kind of story that Narcissu tells its readers, this aesthetic feels just right. 

The approach of minimalism doesn’t stop with the visual or the sounds. While Narcissu used novel-style writing that is known for being verbose, the story intentionally leaves a lot of room for our interpretation, their emotions and thought process, their ideology, and nuance. Giving the readers the full picture is not something that the game is interested in. That’s not to say that the story is cryptic, far from it. Narcissu still gives the reader just enough specifics to have an idea of what the story is all about, its messages, and the philosophy behind the ideas. But they don’t give you all the puzzle pieces for the whole picture, the readers have to form their puzzle pieces and fit them in by themselves if getting the full picture is something that they desired. This approach makes the lack of a branching path feel irrelevant because each player might view the game in different ways in different playthroughs. An idea that they toned down for the second game as it gives a lot more info about the characters with an emphasis on details which gives a lot of context to the events of the first game, playing the 2nd game first is recommended.

The story revolves around the idea of living with death in mind, that you will never be like everyone else, living their life as they please, that even if they succeed or fail, at least they still have a future to look forward to. It’s a simple thing, but it’s something that you don’t have. The main characters of the games are patients on the 7th floor of a nameless Christian hospital, the hospice floor with windows that don't open more than 15 cm, waiting for their death. Each with their point of view of what their situation means for them. The fear of leaving the left behind with burdens, the desire to live life to the fullest, questioning your faith in God, is it better to just give up? The game delved into ideas that feel natural to come to mind if one is faced with such a situation. With the premise, it is easy to label it as a crying game, but the game doesn't want you to just cry, the game wants you to view it as a whole package with the hope that the messages might stick with you. The game tries its best for the reader to not be too sympathetic to the characters, they want you to be sympathetic to their ideas in a way that makes you go “Ah, I think I get why.” In a way, this way of telling the stories might leave the characters feeling a little bit bland, but I found it to be beautiful.

Even though terminal disease and death is the prominent theme of the game, Narcissu is a story about living, the script has some typos and the minimalism might not be for everyone, but if the story that it told is the type of story that touches your heart, Narcissu is almost one of a kind. And with the free price tag that it comes with, I’d recommend you to check it out.

98736870.review:
~Spoiler Free Review~

Despite being a VN/LN lover, I hadn't heard of Narcissus until one of my fave developers mentioned it, saying that it was an inspiration to him and was part of the motivation that caused him to start writing for VNs too.  I figured his taste was trustworthy, so I sought out Narcissus and gave it a go, and I'm so glad I did!

First off, I want to mention that the experience is best done by reading the novels in reverse release order; Narcissu 1st was the original VN, and then Narcissu 2nd, despite being released afterwards, is actually a prequel that sets up the events of the first game.  You get SO MUCH MORE emotional meaning if you read the prequel first - otherwise the weight of the events isn't anywhere near as hard hitting.  So I'd recommend reading 2nd before 1st.

As you may have seen from the description, the story centres around people who are in a hospice and already know that they're not going to survive their illnesses - their imminent deaths are not the be all and end all of their lives.  It's how they choose to approach those deaths, and how they live in the moments between, that tell this story.  Narcissus is a really good portrayal of that kind of scenario.  It has relatable moments, feels very real, and is a pretty accurate depiction of mindsets that people tend to have when they're in dire circumstances.  It also manages to portray this without being super depressing, or by relying on trying to throw massive emotional moments at you every five minutes - it's kinda just real.  The emotion comes through in the little things, and the characters are also written well enough that you feel for them as people, so those little things really count.

Since this is quite an old game, the visuals are a little lacking; it's not like a typical VN in that there are plush backgrounds with moving sprites overlaid, and fancy text boxes - it's very basic.  Despite this, the story was good enough that I found myself not minding this at all, and to be honest, it made the moments you actually did see characters on screen so much more compelling, because they were hardly present.  What keeps you in the moment is the great voicing, as well as the story itself.  The soundtrack, although not very large, is actually pretty effective and makes you get attached to the pieces in a positive way, cancelling out much of the potential monotony of a small roster of pieces.  I also like that there are multiple vocal tracks.

A little drawback is that, since there is no typical VN textbox/GUI, you can't see how to do certain things, like switching auto on, which is a big problem for some people.  If you want auto mode on, press A.  The game doesn't tell you this, which is a bit crappy - I read it in the reviews before playing, luckily, so I'll keep passing it on.  Oh god, I'm passing the rules on...  (play the VN to know why that's so noteworthy)

Overall, Narcissus is a relatively short experience (about 10-11 hours legit playtime for me), and though the graphics and soundtrack are somewhat limited, and it's a kinetic novel with no choices to be made, I really enjoyed it.  It really makes you think about life, and might even make you well up a little bit, but among all the sadness, it might just make you smile too.

96167348.review:
I am rewriting my review, since a plot summary is not what a review is supposed to be. Enjoy a slightly better review.

This was one of my first visual novels, and what a great one to start my journey with. These stories will break your heart in the best ways imaginable. With a premise so depressing, like being a terminal patient in a hospice and escaping said hospice, or meeting someone weeks from their death, and forming the tightest of bonds before they die-- these two brazenly sad stories are some of the best stories I have read. Even now, after 10 VNs on my record (and especially then, when this was my second,) this game hold a very special place in my heart.

This game deals with death, depression, suicide, illness, and choosing between dying in a hospital, or surrounded by your family. It is heavy stuff. But that's why it's so good. They handled these topics near-flawlessly, with just words and simple pictures. Even through silence, you can feel emotion between every character. There is no romance to be found; just companions who want to help each other through their limited time. This game shows you that even in the darkest of times, joy can be found, catharsis is achievable, and the good vastly outweighs the bad, if you simply let it. 

The order I played these two stories greatly affected how they felt. I played the second story -- the one with the unnamed MC, first, meaning the money envelope was a mystery. Then I played the first one. At the end, I was crying for two reasons: because the envelope made sense now, [spoiler]and, of course, the death of Satsukis best friend.[/spoiler] I prefer the Second story, personally, but the first one had me good. I still get chocked up about the envelope, [spoiler] Satsukis and her friend's death, and MCs final "speech" about Satsuki.[/spoiler]

I do want to talk about one scene in particular, and how it was reprised at the end. Spoilers for the end, of course.
During MC and Satsukis road trip, they would stop by a beach, for Satsuki to stare off into it. One of these times, MC walks up to her, confused as to why she does this. She says something along the lines of "If I were to walk out into the ocean to die... would you stop me?" To which, he responds "I don't know... we'll just have to see what happens." Then, they both return to the car. I still think that would be the LAST thing you should say to someone who is fucking suicidal, but that's not my point here. At the end, MC and Satsuki do a bit of a photo shoot with a disposable camera, showing Satsuki in a swimsuit; the only recorded moment of her being happy. After which, she takes of her white wristband (meaning she's a resident of the hospice,) and begins toward the ocean. MC calls out to her to ask her one last thing: "Do you want me to stop you? Or, perhaps, you want me to give you a little push?" Satsuki smiles at him, replying "I'm not sure." and walks backwards, into the ocean, disappearing from sight. MC takes the wristband and developed photo, and drives off. I cannot remember exactly what his monologue at the end pertains, but all I know is that is was a strong ending to a Melancholy and Depressing story. The flawless callback to a small yet important scene makes the ending feel so much more impactful, and like a real climax to a sad story. And, the fact that who said what was switched; HE asked, and SHE didn't have an answer. Simply remarkable.

This game has a couple grammar errors, and I really wish the CGs existed, but I feel like they didn't want any colour in their story, unless it was important. That and the response MC made to the heartbreaking question needs to be fixed. Outside of that, there are no issues.

I don't cry. But this game made me cry. I'm welling up writing this, and it's been almost a year! This incredible game will leave you a changed person. I was going to give this a nine, but on second thought, I think it deserves better...

10/10, you won't be the same again...

Soul-moving novel about illness, life and death. 
There's no comedy and no romance here (although there's character bonding).

You should know: the 2nd part is actually a prequel to the 1st. The author suggests reading them in reverse. 

This is more a text-based novel than a visual novel. Get it if you actually like to read. 
It uses minimalist atmospheric images, optional voice acting and leaves the rest to your imagination.

The music is very good and emotional.
It's mostly piano tracks, but some compositions have vocals and are fully orchestrated.

It touches spiritual/religious themes such as theological doubts and the loss of faith, so beware of this in case you're sensitive.

If you ask me 1 word to describe Narcissu I choose "tragic". 
YOU WILL CRY if you are able to immerse yourself in the story.

The word "narcissu" refers to a kind of flower that Setsumi -the charming girl you see in the cover- likes, as it reminds her of Himeko, a very important person in her life.

82377584.review:
[b] Side 1: [/b]

I knew how this would end.

[i] This is the story
of a girl whose heart was standing still
and a boy whose breath was being stolen away,
both of whom die. [/i]

I knew how this would end, so why? Why am I crying this hard? Maybe because it's not about the destination, but the journey itself. To surrender, to resign. Will you, knowing your end is near, fight? or will you accept it as it is? A beautiful tragedy, bittersweet until the end, masterful in its subtlety, "Narcissu" is a work worth your time. Realistic to the core, it will make you go through a concoction of emotions accompanied by the gorgeous background melodies and minimalist imagery. What are you waiting for? - our time on this earth is short, so enjoy it while you can.

[b] Side 2: [/b]

The 2nd side of the story ties the first one excellently. Every small detail in the first side makes now sense. The love for maps, daffodils, rules passed, curses - everything. [i] "If I were a saint. If my prayers weren't just for comfort. Then now, a miracle would happen...". [/i] Beautiful in its sadness, Narcissu 2 ties everything together perfectly, making for a complete narrative, bittersweet until the end. A serious theme presented in a flawless manner. I loved this story, and I wish for you to do too, because.. 

[i] in those dazzling days, those winter days, in times like these, it's okay to cry. [/i]

82053988.review:
Narcissu is one of a small number of games that made me cry. It is such as heartbreaking and beautiful game, and I'm so glad I got to play it.

Narcissu is split into two stories: Narcissu 1st and Narcissu 2nd. Narcissu 1st is about a man who is admitted to 7F, the seventh floor of the hospital, due to his terminal illness. There he meets Setsumi, a woman who is also terminally ill. The man finds out that 7F is the hospice, where the terminally ill come to be treated until they die. Additionally, he finds out that other than terminal illness, he and Setsumi have something else in common: both would rather die elsewhere other than in 7F or at home. Thus, they leave the hospital and set off on a journey, the final journey of their lives.

Narcissu 2nd takes place years before Narcissu 1st and follows a younger Setsumi, before her admission into 7F. Setsumi meets Himeko, a terminally ill patient, and the two strike up a friendship. From Himeko, Setsumi learns about cars, maps, and adventure, and in spite of her illness, Himeko's spirit seemingly never waned. Himeko's backstory is also revealed, in which she used to help other patients in 7F before her diagnosis of terminal illness. In similarity to Narcissu 1st, Himeko wants to take one final journey, and thus she and Setsumi set off to do so.

Both stories deal with the effects of terminal illness and loss. It is not easy to deal with the fact that someone close has a terminal illness. The entire livelihood of the one diagnosed with the illness is changed, and he/she will have to experience a slow but eventual death. The person's family and friends have to deal with knowing that loss will come in the near future, for there is nothing they can do to prevent death and raise the person's spirits to the fullest potential. The man, Setsumi, and Himeko realize these facts all too well. 7F should not be the place to die, where they're surrounded by medical staff and equipment in a setting that is all too familiar and painful. Home also should not be the place to die, where they're surrounded by family and friends who can only watch them fade away, who then must face the pains of loss right in front of them. There must be a better option.

When I read the game description, I was reminded of a famous line in William Shakespeare's [i]Romeo and Juliet[/i]: "A pair of star-crossed lovers take their life." Shakespeare literally tells his audience in the intro of his famous play that Romeo and Juliet will inevitably take their lives. The game description does the same: "This is the story of a girl whose heart was standing still and a boy whose breath was being stolen away, both of whom die." Now that sounds depressing, but despite the fact that death is inevitable, why does this game exist; why does [i]Romeo and Juliet[/i] exist? Then I remembered: a story is never just about the resolution, and an adventure is never just about the destination. They are about everything in between: the preparation, the journey, the setbacks, the miracles, the seemingly little things that culminate into something memorable. During their road trip, the man and Setsumi bought clothes, had their picture taken, and slept under a roof that was neither a hospital's or a home's, before finally reaching flowers, beaches, and open water. Before their last goodbyes, Setsumi and Himeko had food and drinks together, read maps, and climbed a mountain to reach out to open skies. Yes, death is inevitable, especially under the circumstances of terminal illness, but it is the time spent beforehand that truly matters.

In the end, the interactions and development of these characters, followed by their drive to truly live before they die and their subsequent journeys away from familiarity culminate into an absolutely sweet, heartbreaking, and above all, beautiful game. It is true that we will inevitably say our goodbyes sometime later, but it is important to live in the now. Time is precious, so make the most of it, and life will become that much sweeter.

77494607.review:
Wooow... This was a roller coaster of emotions packed into a stunning visual novel. I cried. A lot. More than what I was expecting.

Short kinetic visual novel Narcissu has two stories that each deal with a terminal illness. All I can say is that you will experience strong gut-punches from emotions as you read this novel. Playing this and hoping to disappear into a fantasy world is not going to happen. The story of this visual novel is unadulterated, unfiltered, and stays true to the difficult, painful truth it explores.

If you want to read through this exquisitely written visual novel, there are a few things you should take into account. The narrative is divided into two stories. Although the second story takes place quite before the first story chronologically, reading the stories in either order won't significantly alter the reading experience. In addition, it is important to note that some of the content may bore some readers. This vn is rife with slow storytelling, a lack of character growth, and character CG. Narcissu might not be for you if you prefer watching the characters interact throughout the entire narrative and don't want to be stuck staring at still images of clouds, hospital rooms, and all the other background CG used.

Personal thoughts:
I really liked this visual novel, so I wasn't bothered by the slow pacing at all. I think of it as the reader taking on the role of the storyteller and gradually feeling the suffering that the characters we follow are experiencing, as well as the slow, monotonous life that they are forced to lead by the circumstances of their lives. I really liked how little character-specific computer-generated imagery was used. I felt lonely and depressed as a result of it. It fit in well with the way Narcissu is attempting to tell its story. That is, at least, how I see it.

As a final note, sadness with a large portion of crying and heartache is all you'll know when you finish this visual novel…

76422444.review: This is a very nice game/ visual novel. Its short because its a kinetic novel without other routes but it does its job. Its a very bittersweet story and it made me cry for a long time. Definitly leaves a lasting impression

76387260.review:
Narcissu is a VN about the lives of three people with a terminal illness. It has two parts and I'll talk about both of them.

Narcissu 1st follows Yuu Atou, a man who, due to his worsening condition, is sent to be taken care of on the 7th floor of the hospital. This is where he meets Setsumi Sakura, a girl who also has a terminal illness, and discovers that the 7th floor (referred to as "7F") is where patients with illnesses like theirs are sent to die with no hope of ever getting better. In an effort to find some meaning and closure in their lives, Yuu and Setsumi set off on a road trip, determined not to die on 7F.

Narcissu 2nd is the prequel to Narcissu 1st and follows a younger Setsumi, before she is admitted to 7F. She meets a young woman named Himeko Shinohara in a hospital, who has been admitted to the 7th floor. Himeko is a rambunctious young woman despite her illness, loves cars, maps, and adventure, while Setsumi is quiet, stoic, and reserved. Despite this, they become friends and share a commonality due to their illness.

Both parts deal with a common theme that most people can relate to, which is loss. It's handled very well, so well I cried near the end of both of them because the imagery, writing (besides some spelling errors), and soundtrack is so good that it hits just the right notes to replicate the feeling of loss. It's what a good story does ― it develops the characters and makes them real enough for you, the reader, to care about them, and this is what Narcissu does very well.

It took me around 8 hours to finish Narcissu (which is quite long for a free VN), but it depends on how fast you read and whether you have voice mode on and you're just listening to the story rather than reading it. All in all, I recommend this VN, especially if you enjoy great characters and writing.

75888874.review: Sad but good kind of sad.

75709759.review:
I recall once a line by Thomas Bernhard that everything is ridiculous when one thinks of death. I forgot exactly how he articulates the idea but it more or less expressed how much changes when one is confronted with the specter of illness and mortality. What truly matters and what can anyone outside understand about lives developed in the face of death, year after year?

I can’t help but think the same whenever I read Narcissu. At its core, it is extremely minimalistic and short, having few of the accoutrements of most other VNs. A cast of two, few backgrounds and CGs, and an anemic playtime for anyone used to the marathon lengths of the likes of Fate/Stay Night or Muv Luv. But in many regards, this allows for a concise focus on the simple but poignant center of the VN, two terminally ill patients and what it is that matters, that anything matters alone on the precipice of death. 

The narrative itself is simple, two patients steal a car on their way to a place away from the hospital or home, a death away from the hospital or home. We are succinctly told that

[i]This is a story of so many things.[/i]
[i]But most of all ...[/i]
[i]This is the story[/i]
[i]of a girl whose heart was standing still[/i]
[i]and a boy whose breath was being stolen away,[/i]
[i]both of whom die.[/i]

There is only one inexorable conclusion. But knowing the events themselves says nothing about the VN, it is how it conveys the gravitas of death. Mortality and illness rob the two of any normal life, it makes even the smallest, trivial actions a bare struggle during their journey. But there is no melodramatic self-pity, no (excessive) soliloquys, no convenient surrender, it may not be boldly defying fate but it stands upright in its resignation. For a VN so occupied with death, it expresses the greatest appreciation for the smallest, most insignificant moments that make up life.
Perhaps not for everyone, but certainly worth the small time commitment for anyone with a remote interest.

67978725.review:
If you're looking to see if visual novels are right for you & don't mind a darker story, then Narcissu is an easy sell. With their strong stories, writing, & characterization being matched well by bittersweet OSTs, both Narcissu & Narcissu Side 2nd are more than worth the read, although my preference is definitely for the shorter, more focused story of Narcissu.

Narcissu: A short 2-2.5 hour reading time is all it takes for this bittersweet read to fulfill its purpose, but that's not to say the writing is devoid of poetic flair & exposition. I'd say that, even if you're perhaps unsure about the setting & maybe even the medium as a whole, Narcissu's short length & well told story are enough to justify seeing it through to its conclusion..

Narcissu Side 2nd: About twice the length of "Narcissu" thanks to a more fleshed out cast & (slightly) bigger scope. If you enjoyed Narcissu, then Side 2nd is a no brainer, offering further development & insight to the residents of Floor 7F. Again, a strong OST & improved art help bring the world to life, but it's the writing that really sets it apart from other free reads.

Overall, an absolutely solid recommendation - especially as you've nothing to lose besides perhaps a few hours of your time. As far as first VNs go, you could do a hell of a lot worse than Narcissu, but please don't think that it's all the medium has to offer if you do wind up not enjoying it, as it's one of the most varied & flexible storytelling mediums out there.

I went back and forth a lot about whether I was going to recommend it.

First off, if you have depression or anxiety about death or being terminally ill, do not play this game. It's a very sad story, which between both novels, there was not a single chapter where the overtone of sadness didn't drown out any potential for humor or cheerfulness.

My only two complaints were that the visuals were definitely lacking relative to other visual novels that I've played, and the story was confusing at times, due to the stories being chronologically out of order, and the narrator switching perspectives between the stories.

With all that being said; the story, soundtrack and voice acting were fused together so well, that I was actually brought to tears. Make sure you read the second side FIRST, it comes before the first one chronologically, and reading it the other way around would make things pretty confusing.

Be warned, there are no choices in this one, and there are no happy endings.

62348413.review:
Review of Narcissu 1st 

This is beatiful and sad but warming experience. I wouldnt even call this a game, its just a Visual Novel with no player input. Its like reading a book but its accompanied by beautiful music and tasteful pictures.

I dont think ive ever played anything like this. Ive finished 1st game in 95 minutes and i would urge you to play this game in one session, it truly is a unique experience. 

This "game" is a masterpiece. Music is beautiful, art is very fitting. Its just so great to find something like this. Most VNs offer huge storylines with complex twists - they usually require a lot of hours to fully explore them. This one managed to present excellent story, atmosphere and realism and feelings in just 95 minutes. It has many sad, melancholic moments. It has warm moments that will put a smile on your face (i know they put a smile on mine). 

Theres one more thing Narcissu did - i dont think there is any game that comes even close - It managed to show us, desribe to us true feelings of sick people - what comes through their head, what do they do, what are they thinking about, all of this just in 95 minutes of your time.

There are 2 lines that stuck with me:

"Purpose has been born, so was the fear of losing that purpose."
"We had a map, we had our meds, we had a car but we had no time. We had no future."


I know i will be remembering this game for a long time.
 If you have an hour and a half to spare, please try this piece of a game, it is truly amazing.

Review of Narcissu 2nd:

Didnt play yet, will play tomorrow.

First off, you will only love Narcissu if you are a person who loves narratives, and can truly enjoy a masterfully crafted story. This will be true even more so if you enjoy books and visual novels in general; those only interested in gameplay and have no intention to immerse themselves in a story will not find Narcissu to be enjoyable, it takes patience and a willingness to open up to the narrative. Narcissu's 'fading' artwork, dialogue, and minimalist UI are artistic choices that also add to the mood and tone of the very tragic story which I believe fit the game almost too well. These decisions add to a style that makes you wish you knew more about the characters in the game, adding to the narrative and adding a bittersweet feeling to the larger conversation taking place in the game itself.

The story of Narcissu 1st and 2nd was some of the most eye opening work I've ever experienced, to understand and empathize with the people stuck in the metaphorical "waiting room". While we all bear the burden of a fleeting life and inevitable death, Narcissu manages to convey the struggle of knowing that without a doubt, on any given day, you can die. This connects to the sad and inevitable fate of a youth(s) having to confront this unbearable burden so early in life; the topic is beyond depressing, but it really does show the silver lining of life and makes you question many commonly brushed off questions like, "Is there a circumstance in which breaking the law is acceptable?". Understanding how meaningful that a last experience is to somebody is very difficult and illustrates just how beautiful life is, despite the existential crisis we all face and that even a little bit of joy can make our lives worth living.

Thank you for reading through this, I hope more people will receive the blessing of experiencing Narcissu; make sure to bring some tissues for the feels train!

Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a short and free kinetic visual novel that focuses on terminally ill people in a hospice. As you might expect from this concept, it's a pretty sad story but it's definitely worth experiencing at least once. The game has 2 different stories, 1st focuses on an unnamed male character as the protagonist and a quiet woman named Setsumi. 2nd is a prequel that features Setsumi as the protagonist, but it focuses more on a former christian named Himeko. I thought it was really cool how 2nd links back to 1st and explains a lot of small details about Setsumi.

The presentation of the game was pretty good, there aren't too many CGs but they do show up at key points in the story and I really dig the art style, you can get a feel for it on the store screenshots. The voice acting is pretty nice, some minor characters with only a few lines of dialogue aren't voiced which isn't really a huge issue, and the soundtrack is excellent. Lots of nice piano tracks and a few vocal songs. If the concept interests you, try it out! I really liked it and I can't wait to try out the 10th anniversary anthology project!

48035926.review:
I know, this is a popular storybook. And yeah, I know, I'm probably gonna get some quite heavy criticism if not outright getting my account banned for daring to say so, to give voice to my opinion. But ya know what? That's exactly 'why' I'm gonna give my perspective, as the fear of speaking out against what's popular is not a correct line of thinking. But with that said, I shall simply do my standard review format; Pros, cons, closing statement, and final verdict.

PROS: 

 + Beautiful music. I loved the piano melodies; they were so calm and serene. Then again, I am a bit of a piano nut, so..yeah. ^~^"

 + No hassle. This can just be downloaded and read, no problem, no configuration, no nothin'.

 + Voices are optional. There's voiced and unvoiced mode. I really, really like that. Granted, volume controls are fairly normal, but...yeah. It's nice to just have an unvoiced mode.

 + Most important part; it's free.

CONS: 

- Boring, uninteresting characters. It makes sense, but I literally cannot feel attached to either of them.

- Repitition. In some cases it's good for recapping, but in several moments the MC said the same exact thing twice in a row, back to back.

- Awkward writing. I'm gonna blame it on translation for this one, but yeah....it's not only hard to tell who is speaking when, but also a few instances of typos, albeit forgiveable, are still noticeable. 

- Dull plotline. We get it. They don't have much of a future. let's move on. Seriously. That seems like the whole premise of the entire story, is just driving in a more or less straight line across irrelevant places to do nobody-cares-what, not even the characters temselves really care about what's going on.

- So little is said, for how many words are there.

- No auto-mode. Sure, there's a skip mode, but not auto. 

- Choppy dialogue; literally everything happens and/or is said one singular sentance at a time. Which not only causes a few things to get rather disjointed at times, but also makes it so that you have to press the next button (in my case either enter key or space bar, though some people prefer clicking mouse 1) a LOT. Hence why an auto feature would be nice.

- Limited artwork. Granted, it's incredibly hard to make good-looking art for the full screen to enjoy, especially in an FTP book, buuuuuuuuut all the illustrations are made using just a single thin strip across the middle of the screen in mandatory windowed mode. I personally prefer windowed mode in visual novels, BUT the option between the two is nice.

Ultimately, it's nice that there are free Ebooks like this around, to give poorer readers and readers on a budget something to enjoy, but being free doesn't excuse it from it's mistakes. And it's flaws, while seemingly small, outnumber it's perks. Ultimately, this is a good story to read if you're bored out of your mind but can't afford a better VN, or if you've already read all the good ones and just wanna somehow read all the visual novels steam has to offer; maybe a collector or something, I dunno. But all in all, it wasn't a TERRIBLE story either. But if you thought you were bored before reading this visual novel, then your previous boredom would seem vibrant and lively compared to the boredom afterwards.

3 out of 10; below average score.

43961898.review:
Narcissu is probably the most depressing visual novel I've read so far. In fact, it's the ONLY depressing visual novel I've played so far. I've played quite a few VNs, and I love sad stories, but this was beyond sad. It was truly depressing.

In the very beginning, I was quite skeptical, considering on how it differenciated from most visual novels, but as soon as I deeper in the game, I could see that none of the differences really mattered, and if anything just made it that more interesting. After completing both games, I can honestly say that my favorite part, and probably everyones, was the story its self. It was so deep and emotional on such a higher level than other VNs I've read. Also, most music in visual novels aren't very good, and can sometimes be annoying, but the music fit so perfectly, and really set the mood for each scene and part of the story, and only made the visual novel that much better!

9/10

Side Note: I do not recommend Narcissu to those of younger age and/or those who can't take heavy content, especcially emotional content, as the story focuses around death. But, if you think you are up to taking this heart-crusher, then grab a tissue box, some ice cream, and a pair of headphones, cause things are about depressing!

43303195.review:
Narcissu follows 3 different people, and their time in the 7th floor, where hospital patients with no hope of getting better live out the remainder of their days. It's such a sad and melancholy story, that makes you value your life and the lives of those around you so much more. It's packed with emotion and sadness, but has a very valuable story among all the feels it brings.

I really enjoyed this visual novel. There are no choices, just a sit back and listen story split into two parts. (I recommend B side, or the second story first, as it takes place [i]before[/i] A side or the first story.) It deals with the topic of death, regrets, religion and suicide so if these are sensitive topics for you, I would avoid this novel. Otherwise, this is a very good story from the perspective of people who should have no hope left, and what they do with their situations when the world has not been kind to them.

Narcissu is a very "real" game. Everything that takes place in the story is something that could very well happen in real life. It's a slice of life novel, for when your slice of life isn't what you always hoped it would be. It's a heartwarming and beautifully told story, just as long as you can hold your tears back for the endings.

Like most small project visual novels, the translation is a bit off. You can still make sense of the story, but some things may be a bit confusing to understand in an English-speaking audience. The soundtrack is beautifully done, as is the artwork. It was strange to me that only a small sliver of art was shown with the dialog, but it grows on you and isn't too big of an issue unless you highly prefer that the art takes up the entire screen.

I really enjoyed this novel, and if you did too you should look into their second version of this game, the 10th Anniversary Project. It's free, sad, and wonderfully done for what it is.

42257488.review:
Do not come into Narcissu expecting engaging gameplay. This game is a visual-novel and a kinetic one at that, meaning that it does not contain any choices, just like actual books. 

Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a game collection consisting of two games. The main one (Narcissu 1st) tells the story about two terminally ill patients escaping from their hospital and setting of on a journey of their lifetime. It is short (took me about two hours to finish) has good atmospheric music and tells a pretty good and depressing story. However it must be noted that Narcissu has lots of corny and clichéd lines.

The follow-up, "Narcissu 2nd" is actually a prequel to the first game, that helps you make better sense of the first Narcissu game. This game is a bit longer (about 4 hours long). The soundtrack is really good in this one as well and the story, while containing lots of corny dialogue, is overall pretty good and made me feel a bit depressed. That is one strong indicator that you have made a good game, since I am someone that rarely feels depressed after reading a fictional story.

Give this game a try, it is free and does not take too long to complete. 

This game gets a 7/10 for its story and atmospheric music, but is dragged down from a higher score by its corny and clichéd lines.

42256474.review: These are both rather short visual novels exploring the themes of illness and death from the perspective of hospice patients. They're short and touching stories, and I definitely think it's worth taking the time to read them (especially at the low, low price of free). I played them in chronological order, but the author actually recommends reading 2 before 1. I have to say it would really change your experience, though either order is good.

42123078.review:
I've played this visual novel a while ago. Just decided to write a review.

First off, I really appreciate this as a work of art. It doesn't have to say much, but it does speak volumes. The contrasts of life and living, versus death and dying are very apparent. The 1st and 2nd are in slightly different settings, but it all revolves around how sometimes even life, when young, may be tragically cut short. The dying have to come to terms with it, even beyond accepting that fact. What matters is how they deal with it, and how much it transformed what they thought had in store for them in the future.

This is a "series", I should call it, which is really a story that comes in 2 parts in different perspectives. One of the living, one of the dying. It's hard to compare it to other games and novels I've read, because they don't often come to such depths, at least seriously. I would say this is worth a read in case you ever come to face such a reality.

41272673.review:
As a program, and perhaps even from the perspective of game design, Narcissu is merely good.  Some script errors, mildly annoying voice acting in a couple spots, but generally well put together for hobby work released for free.
With that out of the way, however, I must say that this is easily among if not the best story I've ever experienced; I can not praise it enough.  For me, it is an utterly perfect progression of conviction, desperation, resignation, melancholy, and closure.  Narcissu never lets up for a second.  There is so much hurt and yet so much hope contained in this visual novel.  This is definitely something I will pass down to any family I may have in the future.

To all of those who've worked to bring Narcissu to live over more than a decade now, thank you from the bottom of my heart.

40703391.review: Just to start with, I have played many games over the years. Probably in the higher percentile of gamers. I have not played many visual novels as of yet. But playing Narcissu I am completely taken aback. It was utterly one of the most heart felt, emotional  stories I have ever read. I was very glad to go along for the ride. The story was top notch. Somehow still finding a connection with another human being going through the same experience. The emotianal ride of two people that had found each other in the later years of there short lives was nothing short of inspirational. There is much more I could contemplate on about the story, but I think you have to experience it yourself. To let let you know.... it is definately not a feel good story, because there is no true happy ending. 40628280.review:
Two terminal cancer patients in their early 20's run away from a hospice because apparently Asian parents are so strict and cold-hearted that simply communicating how you want to spend your last months is not an option on the table. Better steal dad's car while he's visiting the doctor's office.

Please enjoy 3 hours of them buying rice balls and sitting in the car while it's raining. The same sentences will be repeated over and over and over while sad piano music is playing. When there's any dialog at all, the girl will just respond with "not really", "okay" and "..." in 90% cases.

[spoiler]In the end the girl commits suicide by walking into a winter sea apparently so that they never find her corpse or only extremely disfigured, so that she can get back at her mom for the above mentioned lack of communication. The man gets scared and goes back to hospice.[/spoiler]

Honestly, it's just another pointless spin on the dating sim formula. Barely fleshed out self-insert male protagonist, "wounded puppy" girl you can pity, most of the story is just pointless descriptions of shopping, eating, washing oneself, buying gas, etc, so that you can imagine yourself caring for your terminal cancer waifu.

And so you have it. There's really a fetish for everything.

P.S. This particular visual novel was one of the first handful to be translated into English back in the mid-2000's, which accounts for its relative popularity in the West, even though as far as VN's go this one is incredibly dry and devoid of almost any character.

40533940.review:
Won't be the first time you read this but it is good advice so I'm repeating it here before reviewing : Play Narcissu Side 2nd before Narcissu 1st because it will help make sense of some of the topics Setsumi talks of and you will see where they originated.

One thing I noticed is the difference in the tone & positivity Side 2nd has compared to the 1st, they both are on the subject of suicide/suicidal thoughts but it is more a journey of discovery for Setsumi in the 2nd as Setsumi witnesses the thoughts of an upbeat & lively Himeko who appears more accepting of her fate. 
Another detailed part of Narcissu Side 2nd is how it includes the Hospice & it's Catholic support which added a depth not seen in Narcissu 1st, to me it 'painted' a more complete picture by adding this religious aspect that subtly pointed towards the 'sin' of suicide. I'm not sure if this was intentional or if it was included for the reader to understand the beliefs being a Catholic (Himeko has Catholic upbringing) brings towards a serious topic like this. 
The translation of the 2 Narcissu VNs differs between Agilis and Haeleth, for me Agilis' translations were more direct yet emotional though Haeleth's versions added more depth to the story and seemed to have additional 'conversations' and came across as a more academic work wanting to include every detail just as a student would aim for in their thesis. 
In my view both translations are worth reading because it helps give a 'complete' visual experience of the novel and, after all, isn't that the purpose with VNs?

Narcissu 1st is a few chapters shorter than Side 2nd and delves straight into Yuu Atou (the Male protagonist) being diagnosed with lung cancer & upon entering 7th floor encounters Setsumi who now becomes a role similar to Himeko's in Side 2nd except Setsumi is much more reserved in personality. Yuu discovers Setsumi's desire to not finish up at home or at 7th floor so the two go off on an adventure that really captures the Reader as Yuu & Setsumi experience decisions that are both thrilling for them but also opens up a side to Setsumi that maybe she craved the whole time she was at 7th floor and that is - would someone care enough to want to stop her decision or would they respect it and honour it?

Between the 2 VNs the 'journeys' were similar yet from different perspectives in that Himeko was facing the same choices that Setsumi did in the 1st yet they were also shaped for Setsumi by Himeko. The music is exceptionally good and whether you do Voiced or Unvoiced the experiences would be lessened greatly without the music, that's not to say the art didn't play it's part because it did help add to the Visual side and complimented the story & the music. 

Overall, this is Free (that was a request made by the Author Tomo Kataoka) and, even though it covers a topic that is depressing because of the finality of it, the writing is a beautiful insight into cancer that is rarely explored from the mindset, beliefs and thoughts of the cancer victim especially as their time draws to an end. The question then becomes do they Live and seek out their wishes one final time or do they wait for the end without any freedom of choice?

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The story, which is divided between Narcissu 1st and Narcissu 2nd, deals with terminally ill patients living in a hospital in Japan. You also have the option to play with voiced dialogue, which is all in Japanese, while the text is in English. There's a few typos here and there, but nothing that makes it hard to understand.

Well, I don't have more to say. If you like visual novels, I recommend this one.

1代和2代的故事承接地很自然，当观者随着故事线向过去追溯的时候，会恍然大悟setsumi的一系列言行的根本起源：残忍一点说最悲哀的不过于这三段相似的生死传承——所以，当既定的结局无法改变的话，那么至少在活着的时候，按照自己的意愿去自由地质疑，发现，然后再去原谅所谓的世界吧。每个人的答案不同，但至少最后，她们都成全了自己，也成全了命运。

However, Narcissu 1st attempts to do so through a bland male protagnist and a flat female protagonist, which makes the first game hard to finish. Thankfully, the second game does an excellent job of showing why the female protagonist acts the way she does, and does so in a way that makes the reader care for her plight and support her decisions. I recommend this game for anyone who enjoys a story about inner turmoil and reflection, and I ask that you try to put up with the misleading first game, which honestly should be considered the framework for the second.

34765718.review:
From developer stage-nana and publishers Sekai Project comes Narcissu 1st & 2nd, the story of a girl who has to choose between 7F and home.

This story focuses heavily on disease and suffering, of a girl having to medicate and go through the adverse affects of medication, and going through her life knowing that she will ultimately die.

I wasn’t sure what I expected when I downloaded this novel from Steam, and I went into it very confused at first. I just knew it was rated very positively, but it sat in my Steam library for a long time after downloading it. Finally, today, after realising I really need to clean some games out of my library to make room on my laptop, I decided to finally open this and play it.

What I definitely did not expect was to be moved to tears by a story such as this. It was incredibly moving, and the story really hit me in a lot of places I didn’t know I could be hit emotionally. The artwork in this really helps to move the story along, and the soundtrack as well, is just so beautiful, it really helps move the story along, and emit feelings in the reader that honestly made me have goosebumps. I have honestly, never been moved so much by just a simple visual novel – this affected me on the same level an incredibly sat film would.

Stage-nana did incredibly well with this story, and I would love to see more from this, and them.

Are you some masochist wanting to drive your soul into an abyss of FEELZ or simply a curious wanderer who's also a cheapskate after seeing the 'free' pricetag..? 

I'm a mixture of the above and I was pretty curious about how 'visual novels' actually work; and well, it's just that- it's basically a story book with a heart-wrenching narrative and apt music to accompany it. 32402176.review:
Some things to note on this one:
It's not a story with 'choices' or 'multiple endings,' it's just a simple read-through, just so you know.
There are two stories here, the 1st is the original story, and the 2nd is a prequel.  It is recommended (by the author) to read the 2nd first, but I didn't catch that until after I read the first one.  Either way works... I thought the 2nd was better than the first, if that matters somehow.
Not that I care too much about it, but the art could be seen as lacking.
The music seemed to fit in pretty well. 
And then we get to the story and characters... This will be tough.

The characters are... not that interesting.  They are bland, to me anyway.  And this usually would be a criticism, but when you go through the story, it makes sense why they are that way.  So, I don't know how to... review this part.  I thought they were boring, and the interactions for the first 90% of the (1st) game are almost cringe-worthy... but I understand why it's that way.  I know this may not make much sense, but take it as you will.  The 2nd story is better with this: some of those characters are pretty interesting (interactions are still a bit weak).

The story is a big 'feels trip,' if you can put yourself in the situations described and imagine it, you will feel strongly about the story, and this is what pretty much makes up for.... everything.  A lot of people praise this, and it certainly made me feel more empathetic at times.  Also, the game is free, so you can give it a few hours of trying it out if you'd like and make a decision as you play.  The story was definitely worth the read.

I, personally, have some issues with the story, but that is of a personal nature: for my review, I'll recommend trying it out and just read above for my 'neutral' take on this.  The rest of what follows is just my personal thoughts/feelings on this.

I felt... that this story 'glorified' or 'romanticized' something that should not be glorified at all.  I know it's a story, and it's expanding one's way of thinking and just a take on things... but I still don't like that at all.  If you read the story, you'll probably guess it rather quickly.

This story also goes into religion somewhat, and presents what I feel is a... one-sided view on things?  I think that's the best way to describe it.  I completely understand why it's included, I know why people feel this way, and I'm sure it's a popular view.  It makes sense with the story.  But it sucks that nothing was really presented to show a different way, a different view to balance this.  So I will post that view here, if you wish to read (spoiler alert though):

[spoiler]
God loves you and cares.  I know it's difficult to understand sometimes, I know it's difficult to see, I know sometimes it does NOT feel that way, and things happen that don't make sense.  It's fine to be mad sometimes.  But He does care, so don't give up on Him.  Or yourself, for that matter.
[/spoiler]

31333449.review:
Well, first... let me just explain my surprise and what grey areas there are in calling something a "Visual Novel". 

I know that, as far as credibility among gamers go, visual novels are among the lowest, most "casual" rung in reputations. However, there are some games I enjoy very much which are often referred to as visual novels. [i]Ace Attorney[/i]. [i]Danganronpa[/i]. To an extent, [i]The Walking Dead[/i], though it is more commonly referred to as something along the lines of an "interactive movie". Even some rpgmaker games, such as the line of games: [i]To The Moon[/i], [i]A Bird Story[/i], and, I assume, the coming sequel [i]Finding Paradise[/i]. 

But the thing is... these "visual novels" normally come with some kind of interactivity. Moving around, examing objects, quick-time events, dialogue options, even some mini-games. They gain the title of "visual novel" from the intense focus on story and that, at times, all you can do to advance the story is to continuously press the button to move to the next line. But they have other features. [i]Narcissu[/i], on the other hand, does not.

That is what surprised me about [i]Narcissu[/i]... That there was literally no gameplay and you just clicked your way through all portions of the story. I'm not going to hold this against the game. It was clearly tagged as such under "visual novel". I'm simply used to, I guess, games that are in the same realm as visual novels, but not quite. So I had a hard time maintaining interest. That, however, does not mean I regret reading through the story. 

[i]Narcissu 1st[/i] I found exceptionally compelling. The thoughts of life and death are rather similar to my own. The tedium from inaction at the thought of wasting away in a hospital, terminally ill. The unbreakable spirit in doing what you want in life and dying on your own terms. Every person's right to die when they want or feel they need to die. I found myself to be rather fond of Setsumi's perspective. [i]Narcissu 2nd[/i] wasn't a bad expansion upon the characters, but it is longer and I didn't feel as interested. However, the epilogue ties things up nicely. 

I kind of liked this story, and I loved the sentiment behind it. As long as you know ahead of time that this is a true Visual Novel, then there would be no reason not to enjoy it. And if you're the emotional type, bring some tissues.

28350708.review:
[h1]More the fool, I.[/h1]

So there I was in the wee small hours of the morning rubbing my sleepy eyes and thinking that maybe I'd spend a few minutes with a visual novel before turning in. That's right. [b]More the fool, I.[/b] I was still awake hours later with moist eyes and pondering what I'd just experienced. Narcissu 1st & 2nd deals with death and dying and the unfair fate of being terminally ill and expiring young before having much of a chance at living. It's also about those left behind. It's a story ( a group of stories, really) that is very complex, yet told in a very simple and endearing way. It's easy to see what a labor of love this is for the author.

A few small pointers:
[list]
[*]Don't rush this one. Set aside some time and take it slow.
[*]It doesn't seem to matter what order it's read in, but understand that Narcissu 2nd is something of a prequel.
[*]As mentioned above, Narcissu 1st & 2nd deal with death. It may not be suitable for small children.
[/list]
[b]TL;DR   A very moving story about the terminally Ill. Highly recommended.[/b] 10/10.

26474056.review:
Narcissu is a kinetic novel (no choices, just reading) about several young people in a hospice (place for the terminally ill). As such, it is a fairly heavy story with none of the fan service/romance type of themes you might see in typical VNs.

I have to say that when I first started, I did not like the art and felt the game was confusing because you can't tell who is talking. The latter is because there is no sprite that shows up on the screen when someone is talking like in typical VNs. After finishing the game (about 4 hours total play time), those complaints are still there, but I was drawn in by the story. I think it is an interesting take on the philosophy of mortality. Just one of those games where you can think about it afterwards and decide whether it makes sense for you or not.

If you are into VNs I think it is worth a couple hours, especially since it is free. 

Tip: When you start a game, it will let you choose between launch screens. It is not obvious that you are actually picking between 1st or 2nd since there is no labeling. You should be playing 1st before 2nd for proper story continuity. You want the left screen for 1st, or right screen for 2nd. If you start the game and it talks about a boy, then you are in 1st. If you start and it takes about a family of girls, you are in 2nd.
