14304054.review:
(Early Access Version Review)

This is a moving visual novel into which a lot of care was obviously put.  The translation is generally good, although some phrasing is awkward, and the story itself is beautiful and will give you a lot to think about -- the general message, I think, can be applicable/relatable even if you are not in exactly the same situation as the characters in the novel.

For a free work, I was also impressed with some of the extras: several different translations are available as well as the original Japanese text; there is a full set of notes from both the original creator and the translators; and the lovely music is on display in a special "sound mode," which allows you to listen to music from either Narcissu 1st or 2nd.

Given that all it will cost you is a bit of space on your hard drive and a couple of hours of free time, this is definitely a worthwhile addition to your library.

*To the devs: (this may have been a fluke, but...) the one technical issue I found was that the game gets stuck at the end of one of the notes (I believe it was the last translation note for N1st): instead of being able to simply click and return to the "Notes" menu, you have to hit the "back" button and then "return to title."  Obviously, not a major problem, but I figured that I'd mention it, since the game is still in early access.

Let me start by saying, I enjoyed what I read in the first chapter. I could infer the malaise and hopeless situation that the main characters find themselves in. The chapter ended with a good sense of mystery about the girl Narcissu.

That said, this was my first visual novel. I don't mean to knock the genere, but I was expecting more 'visual'. 20minutes into the novel, and all I saw was rain, a hospital ward, and some tables. I would have liked to have seen more of the scenes that were described by the text; parents, the school mates, the drivers licence. Even when Narcissu is first mentioned, perhaps I could see the back of her head as she whatched the TV?

I realize things will probably pick up as I advance in chapters, but this left a dull taste in my mouth for the genere. I guess it's not for me.

Some features that I would have liked to have seen:
-A save option. So I can stop in the middle of a chapter.
-A recap dialogue. So I can return to a save or chapter, and catch up.
-Full Screen mode, for immersion.

In short, probably good if you like the genere. Personally, I'm turned off. I may try again with something more up-beat.

13988025.review:
A sad story about the terminally ill who go in an adventure to spend the remaining times of their lives. It will make you cry for days just thinking about what happened. 

[b]Graphics: 7/10[/b]
Mediocre visuals for what it shows. It’s nothing too great, but nothing too bad either. It’s clean and refined; and I do have to say, the character design is top notch. But, this is pretty much all I expected from a free VN. 

[b]Storyline: 10/10[/b]
I don’t know if I can talk about this without spoiling it too much…its very touching to say the least. You’ll cry at the end of it, I’m that certain for sure. If you love romance, drama and jumping on the feels train, this is the one for you.

[b]Sound: 7/10[/b]
There is a whole lot of soundtracks to listen to. Most of which are heavily repeated in many of the scenes, but they are very good for what they are. The sad ones really do get you though, it’s half the reason why you’ll cry reading this. You can even buy the Original Soundtrack for £5.59 if you want to support the creators. 

[b]Gameplay: 7/10[/b]
Decent. I mean you have the basic menu options for line speed pacing, sound, BGM and the lot. There is really nothing new that a VN hasn’t offered yet at this point. But I read the whole VN without any issues whatsoever, not even a single crash or translation mistake from what I can remember. The way the game works will be familiar if you’ve played VNs before. 

[b]Price: 10/10[/b]
It doesn’t cost you a penny to own this. It’s absolutely FREE and anyone can just pick this up right now! And yes, this is totally worth getting. It is worth your time reading all of this, [b]it is worth it[/b], trust me on this one. I would pay for this if I could.

13905422.review:
While I almost never do serious reviews, here's an exception [EDIT] The hell with tables.
  But seriously. Having stumbled upon this gem by accident, I found the narrative hard to break away from until I finished up both novels. Narcissu stands out to me in the fact that with most VNs, you get choices, but these are purely novels; click, read, continue. (Autoplay is also a thing, so it can be presented more like a movie.)

The Good
-Characters one can empathize/sympathize with
-Great presentation of a few powerful subjects
-Excellent use of music throughout both novels
-The options of voiced and unvoiced are available, should one want to leave more to the imagination

The Bad
-At points, it might disinterest the reader due to the pacing
-No inclusion of the third novel
    
 The Meh   
-[spoiler]Himeko's cheeriness might not appeal to some where it did with others[/spoiler]
-Religious aspects, view it how you will.
-Only one overlookable inconsistency between the two novels


9/10, would read again.

Note: This isnt a game, it's a Visual Novel and (at least in Narcissu 1, I havent "played" Narcissu 2 that's also included yet) there aren't even choices or anything. Also there are Steam achievements, but they dont work yet.

Narcissu tells a moving tale of 2 people with a terminal disease and how they spent their final days. It has a very minimalistic approach both in the story and the accompanying art, and there were a few points in the writing that I found weird, but overall it was well written and interesting, with many parts making you think about life, death and how humans deal with it.

I can highly recommend experiencing it - even more so since it's completely free.

The accompanying music is awesome, if you like Japanese music. I am actually considering buying it so I can listen to it normally, outside the game. 

I found the main character's voice enjoyable. Because the voices are only in Japanese I didnt understand anything, though. Ah well.

13353841.review: Narcissu is a sad, haunting tale accompanied by beautiful artwork and music, and it’s a good example of a literary form of the visual novel. 13313332.review:
This is not a game in the traditional sense. You don't have to navigate, survive, move, do anything at all. Consider it a Visual Novel with no decisions points at all. Think of it as listening to a story. 

One playtime of N1 is about 3-4 hours, and N2 approximately double of that. (Notwithstanding the time spent crying) Although the game allows you to save, I suggest taking a Saturday afternoon to finish your first playthrough in one sitting. I wouldn't finish N1 and N2 in a single day though, as both are very emotionally draining. 

The music is powerful. It complements the game really well, and is a good setting for the mood. The theme musical piece of N2 is just beautiful, although very painful if you understand the meaning of the lyrics. This is especially more so when you consider Himiko's background. There are only about 10+ song tracks per game though, and each song track is not perticularly long, so you may observe that the music gets repetative after a few hours. The VN offers a choice of voiced and unvoiced version, in Japanese. I love the voice acting. The tone was well done, and you can feel the personality and emotions of the characters through their voices. It was actually painful for me to listen to it, as though someone who was really hurting was there, right in front of me. 

The graphics isn't bad, but neither is it great. There's no animation throughout the entire game, it is just a series of largely nondescript scenery artwork. It probably would have been rather weird without the art, though. 

There's nothing much I can say of the story without being too spoilerish, so really, just try it out for yourself. Narcissu is a very though provoking piece centering on the topic of death, mainly on the process of dying. I'll not touch on the points raised, leaving the story open to your own interpretation. The writing transported me into their world, made me internalized their emotions as though I was the one actually going through everything. This is a real tear-jerker, although I'm glad its not because it wants to be a tear-jerker. That is to say, the storyline is not written such that it becomes a sad story, rather, the message behind the story generally evokes sad feelings in people. 

I've came across people who complained that the story behind N1 was too linear. (I must admit, I was an idiot for missing the blatently smoking Chekov's gun at the beginning) This is not a detective mystery novel, and to put an unexpected twist ending would go against the point of the game. N2 is significantly longer than N1, but touches on more topics as well. It is the prologue of N1, giving more details of unexaplined things which happened in N1, and giving more depth to Setsumi. Even so, it is a distinctly seperate story from N1.

After finishing N2, don't close the game just yet. Go back to the main page, as you've unlocked a short Epilogue/Acknowledgements. It is concluding section from the author, giving us what the ending after N1 would turn out to be. 

It would be good to read the game notes too, especially the part about translator's disambiguation of the two translation versions and the choice of voiced or unvoiced versions on which to choose for your first time. For my first playthrough I used a voiced version of Agilis' translation and did it in the order N1 followed by N2. Although the author  suggested playing it in the chronological order (N2 before N1), I recommend going through N1 first. There were limited information about the main character Setsumi, and her backgrounds in N1; I felt this actually helped to focus the story onto the important points. For those who don't like the slight confusion of not knowing the main character's background, go with the author's suggestion.

13169198.review:
[h1]Conclusion/tl;dr up top[/h1]
Narcissu, being a kinetic novel, is not for everyone, but those who don't mind a "game" based primarily on reading or who are already fans of visual novels as a genre will be rewarded with a great story that will make you think and might just make you feel. Plus, hey, it's free, so it's hard not to recommend.

[h1]The nitty gritty[/h1]
Narcissu is a kinetic novel released by the doujin circle Stage-Nana in Japan and published here on Steam by Sekai Project. The story rotates around young people from the 7th Floor (the hospice ward). That is, people whose death has been decided. Without saying much as to the plot, I feel like the novel eloquently covers some heavy subjects: What are the things one has to do before dying? Faced with an unavoidable demise, how might people react to take back independence lost and march vibrantly toward their final act? How does one smile at the end, and how do those left behind smile after?

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[i]For people who have experience with visual/kinetic novels, this section is probably unnecessary, but for the unintiated:[/i]
A visual novel generally works like a 'Choose Your Own Adventure' book with graphics, music, and sometimes voices. The "player", usually in the guise of the protagonist, makes choices throughout the story that affect the plot. However, Narcissu 1st & 2nd are Kinetic Novels, so they have no choices and very little player interaction aside from a click or press of the enter key to advance the text (though autoplay is actually the default setting for Narcissu Side 2nd, and the author mentions in the notes that he himself sees it more like a movie). Personally, I'd describe it as a long minimalist cutscene with save, load, and backlog options. The game itself is much closer to a novel or a reading experience than a game, and this, no doubt will be what turns a lot of people off from Narcissu, if not the genre as a whole.

[h1]Answering common questions[/h1]
[b]Length?[/b]
Narcissu was about a 3 to 4 hour read for me. Narcissu Side 2nd (the included prequel) was 5 to 6 hours. Understandably, it might be a lot of reading for some, but both games are neatly divided into chapters, and the save feature works like a bookmark that you can use at any time.

[b]Order?[/b]
Narcissu was released in 2005, and Narcissu Side 2nd was released in 2007, both are included in this release, and I read them in the release order. However, Narcissu Side 2nd is actually a prequel to the events of the original Narcissu, and in the notes for Narcissu Side 2nd, the author suggests reading them in chronological order.

[b]Replay Value?[/b]
That probably depends on the player. The original Narcissu was kind of an experiment in minimalist storytelling for Stage-Nana, so it was released in both voiced and unvoiced versions, as the author wanted to see how the voices changed people's impression of the work, and subsequently Narcissu Side 2nd is presented similarly. An interesting mirror of that for this release is that two different translations are included: one made with the intent to localize the novel smoothly into English, and one made with the intent to replicate the phrasing of the original as faithfully as possible and paint a mental picture close to what the original author intended. Though I'm writing this review after just one reading, I can see how this approach would add replay value, and I intend to revisit Narcissu after it stews on me a bit.

[b]Why is this free?[/b]
Narcissu is a doujin (or fanmade/amatuer) work and was released for free in Japan. When Sekai-Project announced this Steam release, they said that in the spirit of the original release, Narcissu on Steam would be "As free as Steam would let it be," so here we are. With that said, don't take the lack of a price as a reflection of quality, because, quite frankly, there's no rule stating that professionals can't do doujin works. The music and voices are especially standout in this release, and a few of the voice actresses have both anime and game roles to their credit.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1] [i](finally)[/i]
Well, I put it at the top for a reason...

This is an excellent release that feels like a labor of love on the part of the author. To me, it stands as a great experiment in minimalist storytelling (especially in the original Narcissu, where I found myself endeared to the characters even with next to no background given about them). Though the novel (and the genre) may not be for everyone, if this feels like your kind of thing, and you have the time to give to reading a great story, I can't not recommend it.

12968654.review:
"Or could be that, when learned the meaning of death, is also the time they learned the meaning of living"

I wouldn't call this a unflawed masterpiece, but this is a game that leave me to think about it for a very long time. If Clannad is the game that teach you the meaning of life, Narcissu is the game that will teach you the meaning of death.

Narcissu 1st is an experiment on how minimalist a game could be. There are only two main characters, no supporting charactor and few minor characters. Setsumi, the female protagonist is quite quiet character while your character doesn't have a name or visible face. The game recommends you to play in unvoiced version as it has some lines modified but I played in voiced instead. Sometimes the game is kind of boring as a result of this

Narcissu 2nd side explores the backstory of Setsumi and put answers in several questions you might pose during reading of the first game. 2nd also has unvoiced version but this time it doesn't make much changes. The presentation is more cheerish and production quality is a lot higher than the 1st yet the sad ambience is still persistent.

Narcissu 1st & 2nd are not the games that will going to make you cry, and are designed that way to conveys the message behind this game more clearly. It will, however, make you feel sad, very sad for almost all of the running time.

The game together lasts for 8 hours for me using autoplay, which is kind of long in my standard but should be short for visual novels.

Narcissu (1st and 2nd) is a slightly sad, yet somewhat cute story that takes a look at patients of a hospital (hospice) who don't have a long time left to live. I definitely lean more towards the "thumbs up" button than to not recommend it. The game (read: visual novel) have that amateurish feel to it. It doesn't affect the game negatively. Perhaps more the opposite - like comparing a hand-made product to a mass produced one. The story holds up quite well and the background music is solid work that adds to the immersion. I would have liked a bit more depression to it for that extra impact. But that's just my personal love for depressing stories. The ending was quite satisfying. 

By all means, give it a go when you are bored or feel like trying out some non-interactive visual novel. It's a free title. You'll only lose time, but hopefully gain something worth it to think about.

EDIT: Oh yeah. The artwork is decent especially in the 2nd title. Scarce in quantity but it leaves more for your imagination. Manga/anime haters though: Don't bother. This is not for you.

12590482.review: After some time, I managed to finish this visual novel. When I first started reading it I was surprised by the complete lack of choices, since most other visual novels are a 'choose your own adventure' variant. This isn't necessarily bad, but I like to be in control of the main character, even if it's slight. This, naturally also leaves only one route to follow, and one possible ending. This makes replayability.... slim, as well as shorten the novels length. However, the story you do get is pretty interesting, and toys with your emotions pretty well, regardless of the fact that the first novel has no character development, and the protagonist just kind of does things. Setsumi, the protagonists 'friend', is dull and boring. She is overly intelligent with no explanations as to how she knows anything considering she's spent most of her time in the hospital. Side 2nd goes into some detail as to why she knows these things, and is in my opinion the better of the 2 novels. We learn more about Setsumi, and her past, as the story is told primarily from her point of view. Side 2nd was longer, and had a more satisfying end, and there was some character development with the main characters. The soundtrack is.... decent, it does the job, but there weren't any notable tracks that I particularly liked, and it didn't transition very well between scenes. It's nothing special. The voice acting was pretty good for the most part, particularly for setsumis character in the first novel. The same voice actor is in side 2nd as setsumi, but she sounded just as depressed as she is in the first novel, which doesn't make sense considering she still had some hope at this point in the timeline. 12167877.review:
When beautiful art, expressive music, and thoughtful words combine, the result is [i]Narcissu 1st & 2nd[/i].

Written from a first-person perspective, this visual novel often takes you deep into the thoughts of the character in question. Art is very minimal, but used to excellent effect, with Japanese voice acting also included during key parts of the story.

It should be noted that there is absolutely [b]no interaction[/b] beyond clicking to navigate menus and proceed forwards and backwards through the text. The story is completely linear. You simply read through from start to finish, with no choices to be made to affect the final outcome.

What was most notable to me about Narcissu 1st & 2nd was the depth of thought and feeling that went into its storytelling. It made me want all the best for the characters in the story. It made me, on more than one occasion, hope that a certain character would succeed in doing something illegal, if only so that they could help someone else or that some suffering could be alleviated, even if the result of their success would only be temporary. It truly made me feel for the plight of the characters, and I'm not ashamed to say that I cried on numerous occasions throughout both sides 1 and 2 of Narcissu.

The music in this title is mostly instrumental, with the piano making a common appearance in most tracks. There is the general feeling of hopelessness and sadness, but not in a downcast, depressive way (this may have been influenced by my reading of the story). It's more a feeling of acceptance, whether you like it or not, and just trying your best to smile and say goodbye.

This version of Narcissu comes with two English translations by different people, as well as the original Japanese text. Although there is an option to read through the story with or without the voice acting (which only comes in Japanese), there is no option to turn the music off (though I see this as a good thing, since the music adds so much to the atmosphere and feeling of the narrative and dialogue). It is apparent that much effort has been placed into preserving the accuracy of the original Japanese text. Included are also many notes left behind by people who worked on Narcissu, including Tomo Kataoka who is the writer.

The story also raises a lot of questions and gives the reader many things to think about, though I'll leave prospective readers/players to discover these for themselves.

[u]Read this visual novel if:[/u]
- You like deep, thoughtful narrative with a melancholy setting.
- You have an interest in philosophy.
- You have a soft spot for 'tear-jerkers', or want a story that will [b]really make you feel something[/b].

[u]Don't read this visual novel if:[/u]
- You have an aversion to sad things and stories.
- You are uncomfortable with the idea or theme of death.
- You want a visual novel with multiple endings and choices that you can make.

---

It's rare to find a title of this high quality. From what I could see, spelling and grammar errors in the English text were few and far between. The music, art, and writing all meld together so perfectly that I can hardly find anything to complain about. The only possible complaint I might have is that there is no end-game gallery to view all the art upon total completion of both sides 1 and 2.

Otherwise, I more than recommend [i]Narcissu 1st & 2nd[/i] to anyone who has an interest in visual novels, or a sad, yet beautifully told story. Personally, I would rate it among one of the best visual novels I've ever read, and can easily give it a 10/10. Stage-Nana and Tomo Kataoka have produced an utterly unforgettable title and have even given it to us all for free.

Go and download it now. Just make sure you have a box of tissues handy. Oh my [i]bleeding[/i] heart...

12137524.review:
About 4 years ago, I recall myself writing an essay arguing against letting teminally-ill patients euthanize themselves, namely because it was a defeatist thing to do, and that it would waste what precious time they had left.

After getting through Narcissu 1, I realize how short-sighted that opinion was.

Narcissu doesn't boast any gamplay at all; but it doesn't need any.

The primary focus of this Visual Novel is Setsumi, a terminally-ill young woman who has been relegated to living in a hospice for 7 years without any hope of recovery, and how the pain of isolation has already numbed her emotionally to the prospect of death.

Enter the main character, who himself has been diagnosed with a terminal condition, and is checked into the same hospice as Setsumi. What follows is a desperate, yet touching tale about how even those who have no more hope can still fight to pursue happiness and the final choice of how their lives end.

I played Part I first, but looking back, I highly advise playing Part I last so that everything ends more conclusively.

On an ending note: there is a good reason why this story has been reprinted and retold in physically form, and you have to play this VN to discover it. This game will make you think about how precious our lives are.

12089063.review:
Narcissu and Narcissu 2nd have different tones but they're both similar. The writing is brief and the story is linear without choices unlike most visual novels. 

Narcissu is about 1.5 hours long if you're listening to the voiced edition. It's difficult to get into because both characters are very jaded (They have been spending their time in the hospital waiting to die.) It's alright for a short read. I found it more happy than depressing based on how the characters act towards the end.

Narcissu 2nd is significantly longer, about 3-4 hours (voiced) and is the prequel to the first story. The tone is different, the characters are much more happy and you're able to learn the characters' backgrounds. Also, the production quality is noticeably higher with more art and has a short animation. Much easier to get into than the first.

11489556.review:
Vamos a ver, antes de empezar con la crítica tengo que poner en su sitio a los otros análisis en español. ¿Acaso es normal NO recomendar un juego porque no es una novela visual interactiva?
¿No es lo normal informarse antes de descargar el "juego"?
Está claro que a más de uno no se le pasó por la cabeza eso.
ESTO NO ES UN JUEGO. ES UNA NOVELA VISUAL, Y SI NO TE GUSTAN LAS NOVELAS VISUALES, NO SÉ QUE HACES AQUÍ.

Ahora que hemos dejado claro esto pasemos a la review.

No solo cuenta con la primera parte de la historia, llamada Narcissu, sino que también cuenta con su segunda edición, (casualmente es una precuela de lo que sucedió en la primera historia.)
Ya he terminado la primera parte y ahora estoy terminando la segunda. Y la verdad es que tengo que decir algunas cosas al respecto.


1- Narcissu 1, hasta el momento me ha parecido mucho más dramático, interesante y con una historia más profunda. (Si bien yo jugué la versión mal traducida al español que hizo la experiencia de juego mucho peor, la versión en inglés si que es pasable.)
2- No esperéis un eroge ni nada por el estilo. Es ambas historias se narra la vida de jóvenes enfermos, que pasan su tiempo en la séptima planta de un hospital, esperando a que en algún momento les llegue la hora, pero a ninguno de ellos les interesa morir en un lugar tan tétrico o en su propia casa, (la historia parte desde este punto, obviamente.)
3- La narración es correcta en todo momento y en muy pocas ocasiones se hace cargada.
4- Una banda sonora tan simple como magistral. Perfecta en cada momento y que por mucho que se lleguen a repetir algunos soundtrakcs nunca me cansaré de oír.
Conclusión:

A los pocos que están dispuestos a jugar en inglés a una novela visual sin interacción. (Gente que hable español debe haber muy poca interesada); pues le diría que jugara solo la primera parte. Ya que es la más interesante, dramática y buena de las dos. Si se le da una oportunidad seguro que no decepciona.

Si queréis que califique esto como un juego, obviamente le pondría un 0, pero como no lo es, no puedo hacerlo.

Como novela visual, tal y como es, le pondría un 8.5/10
(Ojo, a la primera parte, a la segunda un 6.5/10, ya que el argumento decae de manera notable.)

En fin, he intentado ser lo más objetivo posible sin tener en cuenta de que se trata de mi novela visual favorita.

Nota:

No he visto ni un sólo análisis negativo que muestre verdaderas razones del porqué es mala esta novela visual. Me ha hecho gracia, ¿acaso nadie puede expresarse correctamente?

11314483.review:
Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd are two short indie visual novels about residents of the 7th floor of an hospital. However, those residents aren't only sick; they cannot be cured, and so they wait for death to take them.

With such a premise, you can easily tell the story will make you shed some tears, and trust me it will. It is a sad, but incredibly beautiful, journey, which makes me recommend it wholeheartedly. Also, while there aren't that many songs in the soundtrack, they all are beautiful and really add to the atmosphere and emotions of the story.

On a more technical standpoint, both Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd are quite short VNs (completed both aswell as the epilogue in 9.3 hours) in which there aren't any choices to make. Some might say this lack of any gameplay mechanics is a bad thing, but in my opinion it allows you to stay focused, if not immerged, in the story.

The only things I might complain about would be the few mistakes in the text, the sometimes confusing syntax (though I understand the goal of the translators, as described in the translators' notes), and the rather small pictures and text-box.

All in all, Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd are really worth the time reading in my opinion, even more so considering they are free. Give them a try, you won't regret it.

10857262.review:
(Spoilers ahead)

Narcissu is an unavoidable story. It's the only way it could ever happen. But this isn't enough. What I always wanted to say is, Setsumi wouldn't have it another way. She would travel with someone to a place where there are Narcissus and she would kill herself, drowning in the sea.

But this isn't (only) because she wanted so. She knew every escape route, she had saved money, she specifically stated she didn't want to die neither at home nor at the hospital. What's the protagonist's role, then, since he's but a witness in all this process?

This is what I couldn't decipher. True, Setsumi can't drive, but as aforementioned, she could very well take the train. She knew where she wanted to go, she knew how she wanted to die. Yet, the story was written in such a way that you just had to be there.

Both you and the protagonist know or at least have a clue that she's coaxing you into taking her to her desired place with all her "not particularly..." catch phrase instances. There's a dissonance here too, between you and the protagonist. You are presented to her circumstances before you are presented to his. Both had possessions, albeit not particularly important ones, stripped away from them - he had the license, she had (or was going to have) the swimsuit. So when she says she doesn't particularly want a swimsuit, you know exactly what it means to her. It's a moment of joy, to see her playing in the water. A moment of closure.

...But closure of what, really?

See, we never get to know which condition Setsumi really bears. Her symptoms were specifically described as not to give away what she suffers from so that we have no idea when she is going to die. She's in a stasis. There's no story happening, but there is her desire for a story, for this specific story to happen. To sum it up, her existence is floating, adrift. Waiting for a current to take her to the fate she wants to fulfill, but can't. Or, rather, it's that she isn't capable of swimming. The current is you, the protagonist and the silver coupé.

This is why we get involved, bid her farewell in a noncommittal yet passionate way. To bring her to her suicide was our job and it's all we can do. We're merely observers, but also the only ones who could ever do what had to be done.

Setsumi is a narcissus flower. We're nothing but the wind, taking it to the sea, where it will never grow.

10669652.review:
This gam- it's not really a game, in the traditional sense. Again. Skip straight to the bottom for the TL;DR version.

This is a visual novel style "game" and if you don't like clicking and reading and doing ONLY that, avoid this game at all costs. 

If, however, you enjoy a good story AND don't mind the lack of interaction, play this game, and/or read on. Mild spoilers follow.

This visual novel talks about suicide rates and the somewhat personal pain the young, terminally ill go through, pain transcending the physical realm, coming to hurt you right in your head and heart. The story is well crafted and, while the ending was not unexpected, the message it was trying to deliever was solid, clear and strong. If you have had a friend who was terminally ill (I did) this "game" speaks volumes. As I said, however, do NOT play this game if you do not intend or like to read lines of text over and over and over and - you get what I mean. In games, this would be the tedious "clicker" genre, only with nice story. While Narcissu has a great story, personally interaction within this genre is still dominated by "To The Moon", which, by the way, you should play.

TL;DR: play this game if you like story and don't mind lots of somewhat useless clicking, otherwise, avoid at ALL costs.

10600072.review:
A true-to-life visual novel simulating real-life crisis, depression, torment, and sadness.  Told in 2 parts, Narcissu 1st and Narcissu 2nd (which actually narrates the events that occurred before Narcissu 1st) both bring out the feels in you.  You will not only come to feel that you are just someone who is filled with anguis, pain, and hopelessness after being diagnosed with life-ending disease but worse than that is experiencing the loss of the love and acknowledgement of your very existence as a homo-sapien by the people who are very close to you or those that share a special bond with you.  

You may choose from many translations and having the characters be either voiced or unvoiced which is very nice.  The art style is very minimalistic but is quite effective in portraying the setting and conveying the concurrent mood to the reader.  The audio tracks are also excellent and noticeably alters the ambient setting in a dynamic fashion to which later events may be foreshadowed when combined with powerful imagery.  Both novels are broken up into chapters which also make it very easy to locate and resume from the last checkpoint; and not mentioning a save function that allows continuation from any point in a chapter.  The cream of the crop in terms of enriching user experience, in this review at least, is having the ability to auto-advance text with no manual mouse-clicking necessary.

All-in-all you can be sure to possibly shed a few tears along the way--so prepare some cleanex before you dive in. Even if you arent easily perturbed, emotionally-wise, you can still be surprised by how the novel project its powerful elements upon you to a resounding degree which easily invoke feelings of sentiment for the character.  it is, in essence, very touching text-wrapped journey that recounts the tale of a girl who is passionate about cars and her tireless endeavours in seeking true freedom and the gift of life.

10590554.review:
"Right in the feels. Well worth the free download." - Me

Anyways... my gosh this is an amazng story. I felt connected to the character, and I had yet to see her face. 15 minutes in, I already was halfway to tears. This is the most sad "game" I have ever played. This isn't an interactive game, it's more of a narrative, and a damn good one at that.

I don't want to give any spoilers of the story, because every single word captures your attention, and you are glued to the screen for the first 3 chapters...then you turn the game off 'cus you dont want to start crying. But basically, the story is about a girl who at a very young age is striken withh illness, and has to spend 2/3 of her waking life in the hospital. when she is a young high-school student, she has very few, if any, friends left from her youth. se wakes up one morning after a driving test to a searing pain in her chest, and it's back to the hospital for a while :( . She is given a very fancy room on a new floor sh hasnt been on before; she gets the room to herself (as opposed to regular rooms in Japanese hospitals which have 5-8 people in them), it has a nice lounge, big open ceilings... th windows dont open... the nurses don't walk through... oh my lord. They are leaving her to die :'(... and thats where I will stop telling you.

So far, and I havent gotten all the way through the story, its an 11/10. Absolute masterpeice of story telling. The music is amazing too. As for the game play... like I said, it's not a game.

10250958.review:
Narcissu is one of the best Visual Novels I've ever played, which is odd because it lacks a staple feature of the genre in having no choices.Reading the author's notes he states that he wanted this VN to flow like a movie and have good pacing which really adds to it more than it takes away. The story has more meaning behind it than just tear-jerking/FEELS, and the minimalistic art makes you feel like your a bystander listening in instead of looking at talking heads for hours. After playing both Narcissu 1 and 2, I feel that 1 has a better story and has a stronger experience behind it, but 2 is better produced and has a sadder story. Narcissu 2nd definitely makes you feel for Setsumi more in part 1, and gives you some insight into how she feels.

      I think I should mention that the author states in the notes he would like people to play 2nd before 1st because it's the chronological order. I personally played 1st before 2nd as I played 1st when it was first translated by insani a few years ago. But it definitely would probably be a more powerful experience if you played 2nd before 1st, knowing what happens kind of gave me a weird feeling, it's hard to explain, but I think it would make the 1st game an even greater experience if you had the build up of 2nd still in your mind.

10161181.review:
Narcissu is a classic amongs Visual Novels.

This is the story of a guy being terminally ill. Once admitted into the hospital he meets another patient, Setsumi. She is, like him, going to die. However, both of them want to die somewhere else than in the hospital. They will escape, and travel through a few prefectures of Japan. This is their story. Up until the very end.

Do not expect this story to be any kind of funny. This is very emotionnal and you might probably cry. The storytelling is good enough. Two differents translations are available, and you can choose to activate the voices or not.
I read this visual novel a long time ago. Voices and episode 2 were not available at the time.

I do strongly recommend this "game" to anyone wanting to try the Visual Novel genre. This VN, is linear and there are no choices. No interactivity. Technically, this is a subgenre of Visual Novel called a Kinetic Novel. You just read. And do nothing else. Narcissu is however very minimalistic. There are not many pictures compared to other visual novels. Please do not be rebuked, and read, immerse yourself in the story. Like you would for any good book.

This is very close to reading a comic book, except you have music, voice and -- sometimes -- animated pictures. You have to experience at least one visual novel in your life, the same way you should play an RTS or FPS if you haven’t done so. This genre is not well known enough, it's kinda sad.
A lot of other visual novels exists and are masterpieces. This is a good start for anyone not knowing what this media is.

Since Narcissu is Free, do not miss this opportunity, and try it. You will hate it or love it. But, you have to try.

First of all, this is a book, a novel.  This is not a game where you have choices, and those choices will influence the ending.

As a litmus test on whether you will enjoy Narcissu or not, imagine yourself picking up a book at a bookstore.  The "About this game" section is the back of the book and the pictures are the front cover of the book.  If you like it and want to continue reading, go on and download the game.  More likely than not, you will enjoy the game.  If not, then you should move on.

This game has a very beautiful soundtrack that nicely complements the story, which adds to the whole experience.   It is something that you can't find in paperback novels.  So if you enjoy reading novels but never tried visual novels, give Narcissu a try : )

I've finished Narcissu 1,2 and 3 before 1 and 2 even got green-lit. Tomo Kataoka did a great job for it. Hopefully this will make people read more visual novels. I see this as an opportunity for more visual novel titles to be up here.

The story was beautifully written and it wasn't in any case forced drama. What I like about this visual novel is it's story is feels almost in touch with reality and not something that is far-fetched. One might think otherwise but it has a natural feel about it. The OST used was also rather smooth and it did great enhancing the mood and atmosphere of the story as it progress. I don't know how well the translations were but Tomo Kataoka did a good job. I hope the translators who translate this don't pull down the quality. It's simply a masterpiece, something not many visual novels could achieve. I for one, recommend this visual novel for visual novel readers. Unless you dislike nakige and utsuge, this visual novel should be a very good read. It isn't very long either so it should be picked up even if one doesn't have loads of spare time as this visual novel is considerably shorter than other visual novels.

I don't want to post any spoilers so I shan't say much about how the story is but I truly recommend this visual novel. I was expecting some tears to flow since this is a nakige and utsuge but I almost never cried anywhere harder. This visual novel took that emotion to a whole new level, something not many visual novel/anime can do.

10091875.review:
Narcissu is a Kinetic Novel - essentially something like reading a novel on the computer, only with music, voicing and background music. It's also considered an 'Utsuge', which basically means it has an incredibly heartwrenching story.

Now, onto the game itself. Without spoilers, by the end of it, you will feel for characters, the music is beautiful, while the amount art is lacking, I personally find that it adds to the themes of the game.

This isn't considered an 'Utsuge' for nothing, however. Excepting those with cold hearts of stone, you will feel sad, you may likely even cry. Though, this is far from a bad thing, and it has some pretty thought provoking themes such as, without spoiling too much, the fate of those with no place in society and suicide.

It is quite short read, it only took me a few hours to complete. So if you're looking for a short, yet powerful read, and aren't afraid to shed some manly(or womanly) tears, then by all means try this out. I can all but guarantee you will not regret it.

With just around 2 hours put into it...I feel like I've just barely scratched the surface of Narcissu...

I didn't really know what to expect going into this at all, despite the many reviews that are about this.  I admit it took a little bit to get into the story...and I'm really just on the first episode, or really what feels like an introduction.  But maybe 10-15 min I just got hooked and couldn't stop reading.  Looking at some of the other people and the time with this title I feel like I have a long way to go...and frankly, I'm excited.

The story telling felt awkward at first but when I realized it was like a manga but needing to visualize the majority myself (there are plenty of story card images to help along the way)...I just fell straight into the story and got hooked.

The imagery mentioned above is simple and at times hazy...which I feel like is a connection to the characters themselves.

And the music...probably one of my favorites parts of this thus far.  The music is probably the biggest part of the whole package to me and just the ride I end up taking sinking myself into the depths the music can take me while the characters figure out what they really want of the lives they have...

I really can't wait to get into it more, but I feel like I need to keep watch over myself else I'll lose the time and put myself into a bad situation, especially if I get into more of it late at night. lol...

As I've mentioned before, I'm just on Narcissu 1st right now and maybe 7 or 8 chapters in.  I have no idea how long 1st is...nor an inkling of 2nd, but I can't wait to see where they all go...

10072883.review:
Another brilliant Visual Novel with touching, well written story. Narcissu shows that even text can convey the deepest of the emotion.

To play the 'game', you need to sit back, relax, click thru the dialogues slowly and enjoy it. Just don't forget to occassionally save so you won't bang your head against the wall if your machine magically crashes and you need to restart the story all over again.

Replayability is zero. Once you finish once, that's all you need to do. Except if you want to recall the story later.

As an Early Access, Narcissu is pretty much done and polished - except for blank so-called Achievements - and most importantly it's completely translated into English. I'm surprised they didn't charge a dime for this on Steam.

The only purchasable DLC here is OSTs. While I don't own the DLC myself, it's been said that the quality of the OSTs are FLAC, pretty much what we expect nowadays (who likes lossy MP3s now?). Even so, I can vet for the quality of the OSTs in-game, it's very memorable and deep, perfectly blend into the story and I can fully recommend this set for your listening pleasure.

All in all, it's a free stuff with great presentation and story that you can finish in one sitting (at least for each part). Well worth your time. 10/10.

Narcissu 1st & 2nd, first of all, is a short story and not a game. In keeping with true Japanese style if you want to follow the story chronologically you should read part 2 first as it explains how the two main characters come to meet. Part 1, however, is the heart of the story but is also resoundingly bittersweet, so be warned. 

You follow along on their journey to find one last moment of meaning in an otherwise fated existence. The voice-over is not complete but when present adds a unique connection to an already emotion packed dialogue. It is, however, the soft keening of the somber soundtrack that accompanies each backdrop that will make this story one to remember.

I actually never heard of this Visual novel before i saw it on steam; I saw it on Greenlight, and I voted for it (mainly because I am a HUGE visual novel fan; even to the point of adding Katawa Shoujo to my non-steam steam games). I saw it finally was released and decided to download it immediately. I then sat down and beat the 1st 'side'; and decided to write my review (also apologies if it is vague, I wanted to avoid spoilers, and this is my first in depth review I wrote). 

This visual novel is quite amazing in my opinion; it really brought emotion out of me, something most movies, games, and books cannot do (although there have been one or two games and books, and a handful of movies).

There aren't too many images used, but what images are used are amazing looking, and are very beautiful. The dialog is very descriptive, and it is translated amazingly. 

The music score/soundtrack to this game is just as amazing as the rest of this visual novel; it fits in perfectly, and both sets and amplifies the mood, making the scenes much more powerful. (The soundtrack is available for purchase, and i recomend picking it up if you have the money)

The impact this game left on me is strong, I even cried at the end [I know; I’m a dork ha-ha] because of its depressing... but strangely satisfying and even somewhat happy ending (I know this seems like a contradicting statement; but it will make sense when you beat it).  

I whole-heartedly recommend this to anyone who enjoys visual novels, great stories, or emotionally charged entertainment; best of all is that this amazing experience is free. I give narcissu a 10/10!!

One of the few Visual Novels currently on Steam,  Narcissu is an expirience unlike one I have ever had before.  It isn't really a game, and in fact can't really even be considered a Visual Novel in the broad sense of the term.  It literally is a novel; one with pictures, music and partial narration.  This is a sad, soulful piece of art that also tends to branch away from traditional VN expirirences by not having a palphable romantic streak or a hard, action based storyline. Although I am only at chapter 3 in 1st, I am completely enthralled and did start crying at some of the more eloquently worded scenes of reflection.  Again, although I have barely touched the surface I have no doubt that for all the more abstract and open-minded gamers out there who can accept a touching linear click-and-read this is a must.

11/10

10000639.review:
ALL ABOARD THE FEELS TRAIN!!
Without further ado let's start: 

Story - You ''play'' an unnamed 20 year old man, suffering from an terminal illness called lung carcinoma who has been hospitalized and will die because of that illness, they place him in a wing called 7F where he meets a  young woman named Setsumi, 22 years of age. she has a body physique like a child and has a quiet personality. The story properly begins when the protagonists father visits his son in the hospital and leaves his car keys on a table, protagonist takes them and invites Setsumi to go along with him. The two escape the hospital and begin a roadtrip with seemingly no end goal.

Gameplay - The game is a visual novel with little to no interaction if you have autoscroll on the text, so it isn't a ''game'' excactly.

Voice acting and presentation - The ''game'' has very little of the characters and is compromised of a textwindow and a narrow movielike image, the voiceacting is completely optional but i recommend turning it on with autoplay enabled so you don't accidentally skip any speech.

Overall the visual novel is touching and has a very sad undertone driven by the fate of the main characters (incurable illness) so they both know they will die soon or sooner and the novel leaves a bittersweet taste of tears afterwards so i would conclude this with a rating for anyone who loves sad stories of visual novels definetly a 8/10 (would feel again) but for any other person do not expect too much.

I've just finished the first story, and let me just say... wow. I don't even know what to type right now; it's been a long time since I've been this depressed. The story is about a male protagonist (who remains anonymous, probably for immersive purposes), and a quiet woman who's a few years older than him. Both have been denied their future. Not wanting to have their final moments in a hopsital or at home, the two run away. Initially with no goal in mind, the two travel aimlessly before deciding to finally set their sights on the narcissus fields in Awaji Island.

Do I recommend this game? Yes, but be prepared to feel sad. I really took a feels trip with this visual novel. Also the music is great- at least a x3 feels multiplier. It moved me and changed the way that I looke at things. Anyway, the less info you know about the game, the better experience you'll have with it- that's my opinion. Consider taking a few hours out of your day to experience this beautiful, yet sad piece crafted by Tomo Kataka.

Note- Give it a go even if you don't like the 'anime' style of it. You will only see the characters a few times- most of it will be just settings; you can also chose to have it unvoiced. Pressing 'a' will turn on auto progress if you're tired of clicking.

Will update after finishing the second story. For now, I'm sorta scared to progress.

9957205.review:
Few novels of any sort are dedicated to chronic or terminal illness, especially when they afflict the young.  I'm as close to an expert as one can be on this subject and still be living.  I survived a nearly fatal heart issue at age 18 and had two open heart surgeries.  I also volunteered in the child life department (duties very similar to the "helper" in this story -- basically being a supportive friend) for several years at a children's hospital on the acute care floor, the hem/onc floor and the NICU.

That said, I was really intrigued by this and hoping to find something that spoke to the experiences I have shared with children who I have worked with who are terminally ill and the friends I have made in support groups who have struggled with giant chest scars in their teens, coping with confronting death while your college friends are out partying, learning to change your IV bags while your bff is talking about her favorite clothes, and generally losing your supposed best years of your life.

I was ideally hoping for something I could pass on to my friends who have dealt with these same issues or my family who truly cannot fathom what that kind of life experience does to an 18-23 year old.  Unfortunately, I can't say that this really deals with many of the issues we face.  I believe that there are some really important points it manages to pick up on briefly that healthy individuals may not have ever considered: the families that abandon children in hospitals because it's too much to bear, the isolation of the young in a landscape of the dying elderly, the alienation one feels from her own body -- particularly because of scarring or the presentation of what is considered acceptable by the fashion industry.  

However, I did think this could have used some editing and likely some research into specific illnesses as well.  Portraying nebulous illnesses, sternotomy scars and "medications" didn't really impact me when that kind of stuff becomes your daily bag in reality.  I also thought some of the character switches were clumsy at times, though the pay-offs at times when things came full circle was cute.  All in all, though, I was left feeling like this did not ring true to the experiences I knew of we young folk trapped in hospitals -- though it was a valiant attempt and some people might enjoy it.  I wouldn't recommend it to my friends or families to learn more about our experiences, and I wouldn't recommend it to my peers as an introspective dip into our pasts.

I think my largest problem was the complete absence of the illness, its accoutrements and its physical impacts from these characters despite their being apparently near death.  I get that this isn't a documentary, but truly, being half machine, rooted semi-permanently to various tubes, plugs and massive IVs, and being sliced and diced is such a huge part of what one has to process and your identity while your best friends are just like, "Man.  Essays suck."  The fact that the characters only deal with half of dying is a hard thing for me to let go of, especially when the characters just generally seem to be withering away from a general 19th c malaise.

Barely recommended as a fair attempt to portray a complex subject on which the authors did not have a clear grasp.  Glad someone tackled it, however.  6/10.

9946789.review:
Narcissu is a VN that lacks the typical VN feeling of agency, the feeling of that you are making your own decisicion or dialogue choices.what I mean by lacking is that This game has none of those, oh no.This VN is literaly a VN, a Visual Novel.With no interactions and no branching storyline whatsoever, however.The game provides a strong narative that immerses you with the characters.With death as a theme and a canvas for the narative, death is a inevitable end and This VN doesnt contain any romance.Which is not this VN is about, this VN is about death and of one's experience before their demise.

I recommend this game for people who wants a good and solid story of death told in a form of a VN.
I dont recommend this game for people who wants agency and romance in their VNs ,because there is none.

9932311.review:
I remember I had this on the GP2X handheld back in 2005, except I only had the 1st story.

I'll be damned if I lie and say this didn't have me cryin' my a** off back then.
One of the best heartwarming stories in a visual novel out there.

The Steam version includes 2 stories. Narcissu which was originally released in 2005 and Narcissu: Side 2nd which was released in 2007. Unfortunately, Narcissu 3rd - Die Dritte Welt was released in 2009 only for PSP.

This is one of the best visual novels on Steam. You should definitely check it out.

9931834.review:
Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a Japanese visual novel developed by stage-nana and written originally in Japanese by Tomo Kataoka. This VN tells the story about the residence of [i]7th floor[/i] Setsumi Sakura and her experience during the last moment of her life.

This game includes both the Narcissu 1st & Narcissu 2nd. 2nd being the prequel and 1st is the main story of Setsumi. 
The 2nd tells the story of Himeko Sunohara as her life take a 180 degree turn when she was diagnosed with a diseased that can't be cured, thus she's moved to the 7th floor. Himeko used to work as helper in 7th floor so she kinda used to the situation, but then it all changes when she met Setsumi.

Narcissu 1st set appx. 6-7 years after 2nd. The story is focused on the anonymous Protagonist (just think of him as us) who is terminally ill & Setsumi as both of them realizes their feeling of not wanting to die in the hospital or at home with their respective families. The two of them begin a long journey accross Japan until they find that place...
[b] NARCISSU [/b]

I have completed the game 2 years ago and when I found this game on Steam Greenlight, I immediately vote it up as I think this [u] COULD BE[/u] first step of introducing the Visual Novel medium to the West. Currently the game is in Early Access but don't let that bother you because the story itself is completed & translated. I'm also part of the Closed Beta tester and I could say that Sekai Project did a good job of making the game engine compatible with Steamwork.

Definitely a must have if you are an avid VN player or you are interested in this medium, even after 2 years of finishing this, I still get [i] dem feels [/i] moment :') a Masterpiece indeed!
